A monotone single index model for spatially-referenced
multistate current status data

Snigdha Das1, Minwoo Chae2, Debdeep Pati3, Dipankar Bandyopadhyay4
1Department of Statistics, Texas A&\&&M University
2Department of Industrial and Management Engineering,
Pohang University of Science &\&& Technology
3Department of Statistics, University of Wisconsin–Madison
4Department of Biostatistics, Virginia Commonwealth University
Abstract

Assessment of multistate disease progression is commonplace in biomedical research, such as, in periodontal disease (PD). However, the presence of multistate current status endpoints, where only a single snapshot of each subject’s progression through disease states is available at a random inspection time after a known starting state, complicates the inferential framework. In addition, these endpoints can be clustered, and spatially associated, where a group of proximally located teeth (within subjects) may experience similar PD status, compared to those distally located. Motivated by a clinical study recording PD progression, we propose a Bayesian semiparametric accelerated failure time model with an inverse-Wishart proposal for accommodating (spatial) random effects, and flexible errors that follow a Dirichlet process mixture of Gaussians. For clinical interpretability, the systematic component of the event times is modeled using a monotone single index model, with the (unknown) link function estimated via a novel integrated basis expansion and basis coefficients endowed with constrained Gaussian process priors. In addition to establishing parameter identifiability, we present scalable computing via a combination of elliptical slice sampling, fast circulant embedding techniques, and smoothing of hard constraints, leading to straightforward estimation of parameters, and state occupation and transition probabilities. Using synthetic data, we study the finite sample properties of our Bayesian estimates, and their performance under model misspecification. We also illustrate our method via application to the real clinical PD dataset.

Keywords: Accelerated failure time model; circulant embedding; clustered data; Dirichlet process; state occupation probability; transition probability.

1 Introduction

Multistate models (Hougaard,, 1999) have gained substantial momentum in biomedical research for event history analysis (Meira-Machado et al.,, 2009), where a subject (or a study unit) can transition reversibly or irreversibly through a succession of intermediate states (reflective of the disease status under consideration) via a longitudinally observed process, before reaching an absorbing state (say, death). Similar to the usual survival data framework, the time-to-events are incomplete (or right-censored), and one observes the transition times and the corresponding states up to a random censoring time for each study unit.

The current literature is inundated with frequentist (Wan,, 2016; Gu,, 2023) and Bayesian (Koslovsky et al.,, 2018) approaches to multistate models for interval-censored data (van den Hout,, 2016), where subjects are followed longitudinally at multiple time points and the exact transition times are unobserved, but is known to occur within intervals defined by successive observations. However, it is relatively sparse for multistate models under Type-1 interval-censoring, or ‘current status’ endpoints (Lan et al.,, 2017; Anyaso-Samuel et al.,, 2023; Anyaso-Samuel and Datta,, 2024), where each subject is observed at a single inspection time after a known starting state, so that the individual’s state is known at two time points: the initial (starting) time and the inspection time, with no further follow-up. Hence, current status data is a special case of interval-censored data, and arises naturally in clinical trials, epidemiological studies, and surveys. Unlike longitudinal data, which provides detailed individual-level information on transitions between states over time, current status data offers limited insight on transitions due to its cross-sectional nature. This limitation necessitates specialized modeling approaches, as discussed in Chapter 8.2 of van den Hout, (2016).

The motivation for this work comes from a cross-sectional study assessing periodontal disease (PD) status and progression among Gullah-speaking African-American Type-2 Diabetics (henceforth, GAAD; Fernandes et al.,, 2009). Here, the PD progression can be characterized as a multistate model, where the PD status pertaining to each tooth of a patient is classified into multiple states, according to PD severity, and are current status in nature. The modeling framework is further exacerbated by the presence of event times that are (a) correlated (current status tooth event times are clustered within subjects), and (b) with possible spatial association, since PD status of proximally-located teeth are hypothesized to be similar, and varying with regards to distally-located teeth (Reich and Bandyopadhyay,, 2010). Furthermore, (c) existing literature on multistate regression lacks the development of an interpretable index summarizing the overall risk status of a subject. Specifically, Lan et al., (2017) and Anyaso-Samuel et al., (2023) developed univariate and multivariate regression approaches, respectively, accounting for informative cluster sizes and present risk estimates separately for each covariate, while Anyaso-Samuel and Datta, (2024) focus on the conditional estimation of future state occupation probabilities given prior occupation of specific states. The objective of this paper is to develop a clinically interpretable index within a multistate framework using a novel Bayesian nonparametric model with spatial random effects that account for the intraoral structure of teeth. The index combines the effect of all the risk factors into a single-number summary that informs and predicts the probabilities of occupying and transitioning through the PD states over time. However, note that the generic scientific question addressed in this work extends beyond one specific disease area (PD). Similar data structure and associated challenges, such as multistate models with current status endpoints, correlated pattern, and spatial association, can be observed in other biomedical domains, such as in cancer screening (breast/colorectal), infectious disease progression (COVID-19, tuberculosis), and organ transplantation (kidney graft survival).

In the absence of a unified framework addressing challenges (a–c) for developing an interpretable index, we adopt a semiparametric accelerated failure time (AFT) regression approach (Henderson et al.,, 2020) for the time to the absorbing disease state, motivated by our naive preliminary analysis (presented in Section A of the Supplement). The latent survival times are linked to the observed state occupations by relative increments of time to each state that are Dirichlet distributed. Our hierarchical Bayes framework is the first of its kind, offering several innovations. First, we move away from the traditional Cox proportional hazards regression framework, where violations of the proportional hazards assumption may lead to imprecise inference, and further relax the (restrictive) parametric assumptions of the AFT errors by assigning a Dirichlet process mixture prior (Sethuraman,, 1994) of Gaussians. Second, the systematic component of the survival time is modeled through a flexible and clinically interpretable monotone single index model (SIM, Balabdaoui et al.,, 2019), with the unknown link function estimated via a novel integrated basis expansion (Maatouk and Bay,, 2017) and constrained Gaussian process priors on the basis coefficients. Posterior sampling is performed using the algorithm of Ray et al., (2020), which uses a combination of the efficient elliptical slice sampling (Murray et al.,, 2010), fast circulant embedding techniques (Wood and Chan,, 1994) and smooth relaxation of hard constraints. Third, the intraoral spatial association among teeth for each subject is accounted for via multivariate Gaussian random effects, with an inverse-Wishart prior on its covariance matrix that is centered around a conditionally autoregressive model encouraging association between neighboring teeth. Finally, our model allows for uncertainty quantification of disease state occupation probabilities (SOPs) and transition probabilities (TPs) over time, with individual trajectories described by the single index and thus interpretable in terms of the risk factors for PD.

The rest of the paper proceeds as follows. Section 2 presents the statistical model, and develops the Bayesian inferential framework. While Section 3 illustrates the model via application to the motivating GAAD data, Section 4 conducts simulation studies to assess finite sample properties of our model estimates, and the robustness of our proposed model under misspecification. Finally, Section 5 concludes, alluding to some future work.

2 Statistical methodology

2.1 Model and likelihood

To proceed with model building, we begin with setting up the necessary notations. (2.1)

log ⁢Ti⁢j=g⁢(𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢𝜷)+bi⁢j+ϵi⁢j,log subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top𝜷subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗\text{log }T_{ij}=g(\bm{x}_{ij}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$})+b_{ij}+\epsilon% _{ij},log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (2.2)

where 𝜷𝜷\betabold_italic_β is the p𝑝pitalic_p–dimensional vector of regression parameters, g𝑔gitalic_g is an unknown monotone link function, bi⁢jsubscript𝑏𝑖𝑗b_{ij}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a random effect incorporating the spatial referencing of teeth, and ϵi⁢jsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗\epsilon_{ij}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the random error associated with each response. ϵi⁢jsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗\epsilon_{ij}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is assumed to have an unknown baseline distribution F𝐹Fitalic_F with corresponding density f𝑓fitalic_f. The systematic part of log ⁢Ti⁢jlog subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗\text{log }T_{ij}log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is modeled through g⁢(𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢𝜷)𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top𝜷g(\bm{x}_{ij}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$})italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ), via a monotone SIM, which provides a simplified framework for understanding a complex, nonlinear relationship between a response variable and its p𝑝pitalic_p-dimensional covariate vector, thus offering a pragmatic compromise between restrictive parametric and fully nonparametric formulations. g⁢(𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢𝜷)𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top𝜷g(\bm{x}_{ij}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$})italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) captures how the multi-dimensional covariate, 𝒙i⁢jsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗\bm{x}_{ij}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT influences the scalar response, log ⁢Ti⁢jlog subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗\text{log }T_{ij}log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, beyond the baseline effect, by projecting the covariates onto a lower-dimensional space through a single index, ui⁢j=𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢𝜷subscript𝑢𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top𝜷u_{ij}=\bm{x}_{ij}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β. The unknown link function, g𝑔gitalic_g, implicitly captures interactions and higher-order effects among predictors. Monotonicity of the link function (Balabdaoui et al.,, 2019) ensures straightforward clinical interpretation of the scalar index, ui⁢jsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑗u_{ij}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the index vector, 𝜷𝜷\betabold_italic_β, on the response, appealing naturally to biomedical applications. Without loss of generality, if g𝑔gitalic_g is a monotone non-decreasing function, the expected value of the response will increase or remain the same if the index increases. If βlsubscript𝛽𝑙\beta_{l}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the coefficient corresponding to covariate xi⁢j,lsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝑙x_{ij,l}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j , italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is positive, then increasing the value of xi⁢j,lsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝑙x_{ij,l}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j , italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (with other covariates fixed) will result in a higher value of the index, thereby increasing the expected value of the response. Moreover, coefficients having a higher magnitude |βl|subscript𝛽𝑙|\beta_{l}|| italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | will have a stronger effect on the expected response. Furthermore, exp⁡(g⁢(βl)−g⁢(0))𝑔subscript𝛽𝑙𝑔0\exp(g({\beta}_{l})-{g}(0))roman_exp ( italic_g ( italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_g ( 0 ) ) represents the multiplicative effect of unit increase or change in category from 00 to 1111 of xi⁢j,lsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝑙x_{ij,l}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j , italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the expected survival time, holding all other covariates fixed. For (g,𝜷)𝑔𝜷(g,\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$})( italic_g , bold_italic_β ) to be jointly identifiable, 𝜷𝜷\betabold_italic_β is constrained to have unit norm. We further re-scale the covariates to have ‖𝒙i⁢j‖≤1normsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗1\|\bm{x}_{ij}\|\leq 1∥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ 1, which ensures the support of g𝑔gitalic_g to be [−1,1]11[-1,1][ - 1 , 1 ], and impose g⁢(−1)=0𝑔10g(-1)=0italic_g ( - 1 ) = 0 to have the intercept term remain implicit through the unrestricted mean of the baseline density, f𝑓fitalic_f. The constraints on 𝒙i⁢jsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗\bm{x}_{ij}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝜷𝜷\betabold_italic_β aid modeling and identifiability, while the flexibility of g𝑔gitalic_g captures varying covariate effects on the response. Additionally, we set bi⁢j′=bi⁢jsubscript𝑏𝑖superscript𝑗′subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗b_{ij^{\prime}}=b_{ij}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for j′=m−j+1superscript𝑗′𝑚𝑗1j^{\prime}=m-j+1italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_m - italic_j + 1, j=1,2,…,m/2𝑗12…𝑚2j=1,2,\ldots,m/2italic_j = 1 , 2 , … , italic_m / 2, under the assumption that adjacent teeth in opposite jaws of the oral cavity share the same effect (see Figure 2.1), and let 𝒃i=(bi⁢1,…,bi⁢m/2)⊤∼𝒩⁢(0,Σb)subscript𝒃𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖1…subscript𝑏𝑖𝑚2topsimilar-to𝒩0subscriptΣ𝑏\bm{b}_{i}=(b_{i1},\ldots,b_{i\,m/2})^{\top}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\Sigma_{b})bold_italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

We define the relative increment of time to the k𝑘kitalic_kth state as

Ri⁢j(k)=Ti⁢j(k)−Ti⁢j(k−1)Ti⁢j,k=1,2,…,K.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖𝑗𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖𝑗𝑘1subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗𝑘12…𝐾R_{ij}^{\,(k)}=\frac{T_{ij}^{\,(k)}-T_{ij}^{\,(k-1)}}{T_{ij}},\quad\quad k=1,2% ,\ldots,K.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_k = 1 , 2 , … , italic_K . (2.3)

following a Dirichlet distribution, such that 𝑹i⁢j=(Ri⁢j(1),…,Ri⁢j(K))∼Dir⁢(α1,…,αK)subscript𝑹𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗1…superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝐾similar-toDirsubscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝐾\bm{R}_{ij}=\left(R_{ij}^{(1)},\ldots,R_{ij}^{(K)}\right)\sim\text{Dir}(\alpha% _{1},\ldots,\alpha_{K})bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_K ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∼ Dir ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Letting Ri⁢j(0)=0superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗00R_{ij}^{\,(0)}=0italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0, Ri⁢j(K+1)=∞superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝐾1R_{ij}^{\,(K+1)}=\inftyitalic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_K + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∞, and using (2.1) and (2.3), the observed states at their censoring times can be expressed as

Si⁢j⁢(Ci⁢j)=kifTi⁢j⁢∑l=0kRi⁢j(l)≤Ci⁢j<Ti⁢j⁢∑l=0k+1Ri⁢j(l),k=0,1,…,K.formulae-sequenceformulae-sequencesubscript𝑆𝑖𝑗subscript𝐶𝑖𝑗𝑘ifsubscript𝑇𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝑙subscript𝐶𝑖𝑗subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝑙𝑘01…𝐾S_{ij}(C_{ij})=k\quad\textrm{if}\quad{T_{ij}}\sum_{l=0}^{k}{R_{ij}^{\,(l)}}% \leq{C_{ij}}<{T_{ij}}\sum_{l=0}^{k+1}{R_{ij}^{\,(l)}},\quad k=0,1,\ldots,K.italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_k if italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_k = 0 , 1 , … , italic_K . (2.4)

Combining (2.2), (2.3), and (2.4) completes our model specification. For our multistate process {Si⁢j⁢(t):t≥0}conditional-setsubscript𝑆𝑖𝑗𝑡𝑡0\{S_{ij}(t):t\geq 0\}{ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) : italic_t ≥ 0 } having finite state space 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}caligraphic_K, the state occupation probability (SOP) of a disease state k𝑘kitalic_k at a given time t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0italic_t ≥ 0, denoted by pi⁢j,k⁢(t)=P⁢(Si⁢j⁢(t)=k)subscript𝑝𝑖𝑗𝑘𝑡𝑃subscript𝑆𝑖𝑗𝑡𝑘p_{ij,\,k}(t)=P\left(S_{ij}(t)=k\right)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = italic_P ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = italic_k ), is defined as the probability that tooth j𝑗jitalic_j of subject i𝑖iitalic_i is in state k𝑘kitalic_k. We define the transition probability (TP), denoted by pi⁢j,r⁢s⁢(u,t)=P⁢(Si⁢j⁢(t+u)=s∣Si⁢j⁢(u)=r)subscript𝑝𝑖𝑗𝑟𝑠𝑢𝑡𝑃subscript𝑆𝑖𝑗𝑡𝑢conditional𝑠subscript𝑆𝑖𝑗𝑢𝑟p_{ij,\,rs}(u,t)=P\left(S_{ij}(t+u)=s\mid S_{ij}(u)=r\right)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j , italic_r italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u , italic_t ) = italic_P ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t + italic_u ) = italic_s ∣ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ) = italic_r ), r≤s𝑟𝑠r\leq sitalic_r ≤ italic_s, r,s∈𝒦𝑟𝑠𝒦r,s\in\mathcal{K}italic_r , italic_s ∈ caligraphic_K and t,u≥0𝑡𝑢0t,u\geq 0italic_t , italic_u ≥ 0, as the probability that tooth j𝑗jitalic_j of subject i𝑖iitalic_i transitions to a state s𝑠sitalic_s at time t+u𝑡𝑢t+uitalic_t + italic_u given that the tooth is in state r𝑟ritalic_r at time u𝑢uitalic_u.

2.2 Identifiability of parameters

In the following, we establish the identifiability of the fixed effects parameters in our model, in the presence of (spatial) random-effects. Previous research, often restricted to the iid setup, proved parameter identifiability (Lin and Kulasekera,, 2007) in a SIM for non-constant and continuous functions g𝑔gitalic_g, under the assumptions that ‖𝜷‖=1norm𝜷1\|\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}\|=1∥ bold_italic_β ∥ = 1, and the first non-zero element of 𝜷𝜷\betabold_italic_β being positive. For our monotone g𝑔gitalic_g, a relaxed assumption of only ‖𝜷‖=1norm𝜷1\|\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}\|=1∥ bold_italic_β ∥ = 1 suffices. To that end, identifiability of the variance components of our model is first established in Proposition 2.1, followed by the proof of identifiability for the fixed effects in Proposition 2.2. The proofs can be found in Section B of the Supplement.

Defining 𝒚i=(log ⁢Ti⁢1,…,log ⁢Ti⁢m)⊤subscript𝒚𝑖superscriptlog subscript𝑇𝑖1…log subscript𝑇𝑖𝑚top\bm{y}_{i}=(\text{log }T_{i1},\ldots,\text{log }T_{im})^{\top}bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 𝒈i=(g⁢(𝒙i⁢1⊤⁢𝜷),…,g⁢(𝒙i⁢m⊤⁢𝜷))⊤subscript𝒈𝑖superscript𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖1top𝜷…𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑚top𝜷top\mbox{\boldmath$g$}_{i}=(g(\bm{x}_{i1}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}),\ldots,g% (\bm{x}_{im}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}))^{\top}bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) , … , italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ϵi=(ϵi⁢1,…,ϵi⁢m)⊤subscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖1…subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑚top\mbox{\boldmath$\epsilon$}_{i}=(\epsilon_{i1},\ldots,\epsilon_{im})^{\top}bold_italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, (2.2) can be concisely written as

𝒚i=𝒁⁢𝒃i+𝒈i+ϵi,i=1,2,…,nformulae-sequencesubscript𝒚𝑖𝒁subscript𝒃𝑖subscript𝒈𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖𝑖12…𝑛\bm{y}_{i}=\bm{Z}\bm{b}_{i}+\mbox{\boldmath$g$}_{i}+\mbox{\boldmath$\epsilon$}% _{i},\quad\quad i=1,2,\ldots,nbold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_Z bold_italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i = 1 , 2 , … , italic_n (2.5)

where 𝒁=[𝕀m/2⁢𝕀~m/2]⊤𝒁superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝕀𝑚2subscript~𝕀𝑚2top\bm{Z}=[\mathbb{I}_{m/2}\ \tilde{\mathbb{I}}_{m/2}]^{\top}bold_italic_Z = [ blackboard_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG blackboard_I end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and 𝕀m/2subscript𝕀𝑚2\mathbb{I}_{m/2}blackboard_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝕀~m/2subscript~𝕀𝑚2\tilde{\mathbb{I}}_{m/2}over~ start_ARG blackboard_I end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote m/2×m/2𝑚2𝑚2m/2\times m/2italic_m / 2 × italic_m / 2 identity matrix and anti-diagonal matrix with unit entries, respectively. Let σϵ2>0superscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ20\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}>0italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 be the common error variance and Σy=𝒁⁢Σb⁢𝒁⊤+σϵ2⁢𝕀msubscriptΣ𝑦𝒁subscriptΣ𝑏superscript𝒁topsuperscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2subscript𝕀𝑚\Sigma_{y}=\bm{Z}\Sigma_{b}\bm{Z}^{\top}+\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}\,\mathbb{I}_{m}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_Z roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the covariance matrix of 𝒚isubscript𝒚𝑖\bm{y}_{i}bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Further, let 𝕊+msuperscriptsubscript𝕊𝑚\mathbb{S}_{+}^{m}blackboard_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the space of symmetric and positive definite m×m𝑚𝑚m\times mitalic_m × italic_m matrices, 𝒞ℳsubscript𝒞ℳ\mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{M}}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the space of continuous monotone functions on [−1,1]11[-1,1][ - 1 , 1 ] with g⁢(−1)=0𝑔10g(-1)=0italic_g ( - 1 ) = 0, and 𝒮p−1subscript𝒮𝑝1\mathcal{S}_{p-1}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the unit sphere of dimension p𝑝pitalic_p.

Proposition 2.1.

The variance components of the model, Σ=(Σb,σϵ2)ΣsubscriptΣ𝑏superscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2\Sigma=\big{(}\Sigma_{b},\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}\big{)}roman_Σ = ( roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in the space 𝒱={(Σb,σϵ2):Σb∈𝕊+m/2,σϵ2∈(0,∞)}𝒱conditional-setsubscriptΣ𝑏superscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2formulae-sequencesubscriptΣ𝑏superscriptsubscript𝕊𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ20\mathcal{V}=\big{\{}\big{(}\Sigma_{b},\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}\big{)}:\Sigma_{b}% \in\mathbb{S}_{+}^{m/2},\,\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}\in(0,\infty)\big{\}}caligraphic_V = { ( roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) : roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ) }, are identifiable.

Proposition 2.2.

Given a fixed baseline distribution F𝐹Fitalic_F of the errors and a fixed covariance matrix ΣbsubscriptΣ𝑏\Sigma_{b}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the random effects, the fixed effects of the model, θ=(g,𝛃)𝜃𝑔𝛃\theta=(g,\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$})italic_θ = ( italic_g , bold_italic_β ) in the space Θ={(g,𝛃):g∈𝒞ℳ,𝛃∈𝒮p−1}Θconditional-set𝑔𝛃formulae-sequence𝑔subscript𝒞ℳ𝛃subscript𝒮𝑝1\Theta=\{(g,\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}):g\in\mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{M}},\mbox{% \boldmath$\beta$}\in\mathcal{S}_{p-1}\}roman_Θ = { ( italic_g , bold_italic_β ) : italic_g ∈ caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_β ∈ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, are identifiable.

2.3 Bayesian inference

In this section, we develop the Bayesian inferential framework for our proposed model by defining suitable priors for the model parameters. Posterior samples are simulated through the implementation of Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods. We elaborate on the choice of priors in the following, while deferring detailed derivations of full conditionals and posterior sampling strategies to Section C of the Supplement.

2.3.1 Prior for the regression parameters

Since 𝜷𝜷\betabold_italic_β is constrained to have unit norm, we put a normalized Gaussian prior on 𝜷𝜷\betabold_italic_β i.e.let ~⁢𝜷∼𝒩⁢(0,σβ2⁢𝕀p)similar-to~absent𝜷𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛽2subscript𝕀𝑝\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_{\beta}^{2}\mathbb% {I}_{p})over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and set 𝜷=~⁢𝜷/‖~⁢𝜷‖𝜷~absent𝜷norm~absent𝜷\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}=\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}/\|\widetilde{}% \mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}\|bold_italic_β = over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β / ∥ over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β ∥. Posterior sampling is done using an efficient elliptical slice sampler (Murray et al.,, 2010), particularly suited for performing inference in models with multivariate Gaussian priors.

2.3.2 Model and prior for the monotone link function

A general approach to Bayesian monotone function estimation is to expand the unknown function in a basis and translate the functional constraints to linear constraints in the coefficient space. Most widely used examples include Bernstein polynomials (BP; Wang and Ghosh,, 2012) and monotone splines (Meyer et al.,, 2011) as the basis choices. Monotonicity of a function is enforced in a BP basis expansion by ordering the coefficients, but this condition is only sufficient and not necessary. There may exist monotone functions for which the BP basis expansion results in unordered coefficients, and can lead to poor approximation (see Figures 4.1, and 4.2). Alternatively, higher order monotone splines are used for capturing the underlying smoothness of a function (Wang and Li,, 2008).

In this article, we consider first order monotone splines to expand the function g𝑔gitalic_g in a basis and enforce smoothness through an equivalently constrained Gaussian process (GP) on the basis coefficients, as in Maatouk and Bay, (2017). Adapting the notation of Maatouk and Bay, (2017), we begin with defining a regular grid of L+1𝐿1L+1italic_L + 1 equi-spaced knot points, ul=δL⁢(l−L/2)subscript𝑢𝑙subscript𝛿𝐿𝑙𝐿2u_{l}=\delta_{L}(l-L/2)italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_l - italic_L / 2 ), with δL=2/Lsubscript𝛿𝐿2𝐿\delta_{L}=2/Litalic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 / italic_L, l=0,1,…,L𝑙01…𝐿l=0,1,\ldots,Litalic_l = 0 , 1 , … , italic_L, in the closed interval [−1,1]11[-1,1][ - 1 , 1 ]. Further, the interpolation basis functions {hl}subscriptℎ𝑙\{h_{l}\}{ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } at each knot point are defined as,

hl⁢(x)=h⁢(x−ulδL),l=0,1,…,L,formulae-sequencesubscriptℎ𝑙𝑥ℎ𝑥subscript𝑢𝑙subscript𝛿𝐿𝑙01…𝐿h_{l}(x)=h\left(\frac{x-u_{l}}{\delta_{L}}\right),\quad l=0,1,\ldots,L,italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_h ( divide start_ARG italic_x - italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) , italic_l = 0 , 1 , … , italic_L ,

where h⁢(x)=(1−|x|)⁢ 1[−1,1]⁢(x)ℎ𝑥1𝑥subscript111𝑥h(x)=(1-|x|)\,\mathds{1}_{[-1,1]}(x)italic_h ( italic_x ) = ( 1 - | italic_x | ) blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ - 1 , 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ). The basis functions {hl}subscriptℎ𝑙\{h_{l}\}{ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } can be used to approximate any continuous function g:[−1,1]→ℝ:𝑔→11ℝg:[-1,1]\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_g : [ - 1 , 1 ] → blackboard_R by linearly interpolating the value of g𝑔gitalic_g at the knot points, i.e., g⁢(x)≈∑l=0Lg⁢(ul)⁢hl⁢(x)𝑔𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝐿𝑔subscript𝑢𝑙subscriptℎ𝑙𝑥g(x)\approx\sum_{l=0}^{L}g(u_{l})\,h_{l}(x)italic_g ( italic_x ) ≈ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_g ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ). Since our link function, g𝑔gitalic_g, is monotone, we bypass using {hl}subscriptℎ𝑙\{h_{l}\}{ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } to approximate g𝑔gitalic_g, and instead use the smoothed integrated basis {ψl}subscript𝜓𝑙\{\psi_{l}\}{ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } defined as

ψl⁢(x)=∫−1xhl⁢(t)⁢𝑑t,l=0,1,…⁢L.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜓𝑙𝑥superscriptsubscript1𝑥subscriptℎ𝑙𝑡differential-d𝑡𝑙01…𝐿\psi_{l}(x)=\int_{-1}^{x}h_{l}(t)dt,\quad l=0,1,\ldots L.italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) italic_d italic_t , italic_l = 0 , 1 , … italic_L .

To that end, using the fundamental theorem of calculus for any continuously differentiable function g𝑔gitalic_g on [−1,1]11[-1,1][ - 1 , 1 ] we have

g⁢(x)=g⁢(−1)+∫−1xg′⁢(t)⁢𝑑t.𝑔𝑥𝑔1superscriptsubscript1𝑥superscript𝑔′𝑡differential-d𝑡g(x)=g(-1)+\int_{-1}^{x}g^{\prime}(t)\,dt.italic_g ( italic_x ) = italic_g ( - 1 ) + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) italic_d italic_t . (2.6)

Approximating g′superscript𝑔′g^{\prime}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in (2.6) using the interpolation basis, {hl}subscriptℎ𝑙\{h_{l}\}{ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, and enforcing g⁢(−1)=0𝑔10g(-1)=0italic_g ( - 1 ) = 0, we have

g⁢(x)≈g⁢(−1)+∑l=0Lg′⁢(uj)⁢∫−1xhl⁢(t)⁢𝑑t=∑l=0Lξl⁢ψl⁢(x).𝑔𝑥𝑔1superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝐿superscript𝑔′subscript𝑢𝑗superscriptsubscript1𝑥subscriptℎ𝑙𝑡differential-d𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝐿subscript𝜉𝑙subscript𝜓𝑙𝑥g(x)\approx g(-1)+\sum_{l=0}^{L}g^{\prime}(u_{j})\int_{-1}^{x}h_{l}(t)\,dt\ =% \sum_{l=0}^{L}\xi_{l}\,\psi_{l}(x).italic_g ( italic_x ) ≈ italic_g ( - 1 ) + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) italic_d italic_t = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) . (2.7)

Maatouk and Bay, (2017) proved that the function g𝑔gitalic_g is monotone non-decreasing if and only if ξl≥0subscript𝜉𝑙0\xi_{l}\geq 0italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 for all l=0,1,…,L𝑙01…𝐿l=0,1,\ldots,Litalic_l = 0 , 1 , … , italic_L. Thus, if g𝑔gitalic_g is assumed to be monotone non-decreasing, this constraint can be equivalently expressed by restricting the basis coefficients 𝝃=(ξ0,…,ξL)⊤𝝃superscriptsubscript𝜉0…subscript𝜉𝐿top\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$}=(\xi_{0},\ldots,\xi_{L})^{\top}bold_italic_ξ = ( italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to lie in the positive orthant,

𝒞ξ={𝝃∈ℝL+1:ξl≥0,l=0,1,…,L}.subscript𝒞𝜉conditional-set𝝃superscriptℝ𝐿1formulae-sequencesubscript𝜉𝑙0𝑙01…𝐿\mathcal{C}_{\xi}=\{\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$}\in\mathbb{R}^{L+1}:\xi_{l}\geq 0,\ l% =0,1,\ldots,L\}.caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { bold_italic_ξ ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 , italic_l = 0 , 1 , … , italic_L } . (2.8)

A Gaussian process (GP; Rasmussen and Williams,, 2006) prior on g𝑔gitalic_g induces a Gaussian prior on 𝝃𝝃\xibold_italic_ξ, since derivatives of a GP having a sufficiently smooth covariance kernel are again a GP. For monotone non-decreasing functions, Maatouk and Bay, (2017) proposed a Gaussian prior on 𝝃𝝃\xibold_italic_ξ by computing the induced prior on (g′⁢(u0),…,g′⁢(uL))superscript𝑔′subscript𝑢0…superscript𝑔′subscript𝑢𝐿\left(g^{\prime}(u_{0}),\ldots,g^{\prime}(u_{L})\right)( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , … , italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) from a GP prior on g𝑔gitalic_g and restricting 𝝃𝝃\xibold_italic_ξ to lie in 𝒞ξsubscript𝒞𝜉\mathcal{C}_{\xi}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, defined in (2.8). This induced prior on ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ from a stationary GP prior on g𝑔gitalic_g is no longer stationary. In addition to 𝒪⁢(L3)𝒪superscript𝐿3\mathcal{O}(L^{3})caligraphic_O ( italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) complexity involved in sampling from truncated multivariate Gaussians, this specification requires 𝒪⁢(L2)𝒪superscript𝐿2\mathcal{O}(L^{2})caligraphic_O ( italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) computation for inverting and storing the covariance matrix, posing challenges to the sampling algorithm for large L𝐿Litalic_L. Deviating slightly from the formulation of Maatouk and Bay, (2017) and following the specification of Ray et al., (2020), we put a stationary GP on the first derivative of g𝑔gitalic_g,

p⁢(𝝃)∝𝒩⁢(0,τ2⁢K)⁢ 1𝒞ξ⁢(𝝃),proportional-to𝑝𝝃𝒩0superscript𝜏2𝐾subscript1subscript𝒞𝜉𝝃p(\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$})\propto\mathcal{N}(0,\tau^{2}K)\ \mathds{1}_{\mathcal{% C}_{\xi}}(\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$}),italic_p ( bold_italic_ξ ) ∝ caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K ) blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ξ ) , (2.9)

where τ2>0superscript𝜏20\tau^{2}>0italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 controls the prior variance and is assigned a non-informative inverse-gamma ℐ⁢𝒢⁢(aξ,bξ)ℐ𝒢subscript𝑎𝜉subscript𝑏𝜉\mathcal{IG}(a_{\xi},b_{\xi})caligraphic_I caligraphic_G ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) prior, and (K)i⁢j=k⁢(ui−uj)subscript𝐾𝑖𝑗𝑘subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑢𝑗(K)_{ij}=k(u_{i}-u_{j})( italic_K ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), k⁢(⋅)𝑘⋅k(\cdot)italic_k ( ⋅ ) is the stationary Matérn covariance kernel with smoothness ν>0𝜈0\nu>0italic_ν > 0 and length-scale ℓ>0ℓ0\ell>0roman_ℓ > 0. is placed on τ2superscript𝜏2\tau^{2}italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This specification allows the covariance matrix of 𝝃𝝃\xibold_italic_ξ to have a Toeplitz structure, enabling us to use the circulant embedding techniques by Wood and Chan, (1994) that employ discrete fast Fourier transforms. An elliptical slice sampler (Murray et al.,, 2010) is used to sample 𝝃𝝃\xibold_italic_ξ by approximating the indicator function in (2.9) with a smooth approximant, 𝟙𝒞ξ⁢(𝝃)≈𝕁η⁢(𝝃)=∏l=0L(1+e−η⁢ξl)−1subscript1subscript𝒞𝜉𝝃subscript𝕁𝜂𝝃superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑙0𝐿superscript1superscript𝑒𝜂subscript𝜉𝑙1\mathds{1}_{\mathcal{C}_{\xi}}(\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$})\approx\mathbb{J}_{\eta}(% \mbox{\boldmath$\xi$})=\prod_{l=0}^{L}(1+e^{\,-\eta\,\xi_{l}})^{-1}blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ξ ) ≈ blackboard_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_η end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ξ ) = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_η italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where η>0𝜂0\eta>0italic_η > 0 controls the quality of the approximation, where, a higher value gives a better approximation. This algorithm draws a sample from 𝒩⁢(0,τ2⁢K)𝒩0superscript𝜏2𝐾\mathcal{N}(0,\tau^{2}K)caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K ) with 𝒪⁢(L⁢log ⁢L)𝒪𝐿log 𝐿\mathcal{O}(L\text{log }L)caligraphic_O ( italic_L log italic_L ) computations instead of 𝒪⁢(L3)𝒪superscript𝐿3\mathcal{O}(L^{3})caligraphic_O ( italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), enabling substantial reduction in complexity.

2.3.3 Prior for the covariance matrix of the spatial random effects

The undirected graph G𝐺Gitalic_G in Figure 2.1 connects neighboring teeth in the upper jaw. It suffices to focus on one jaw, as each tooth in the upper jaw shares the same random effect with its corresponding tooth in the lower jaw. Let W𝑊Witalic_W and EWsubscript𝐸𝑊E_{W}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively denote the adjacency matrix and a diagonal matrix with the j𝑗jitalic_jth diagonal entry representing the number of neighbors at location j𝑗jitalic_j of G𝐺Gitalic_G. We impose a conjugate inverse-Wishart prior on ΣbsubscriptΣ𝑏\Sigma_{b}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Σb∼ℐ⁢𝒲⁢(c,S)similar-tosubscriptΣ𝑏ℐ𝒲𝑐𝑆\Sigma_{b}\sim\mathcal{IW}(c,S)roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_I caligraphic_W ( italic_c , italic_S ) with degrees of freedom c=m/2+2𝑐𝑚22c=m/2+2italic_c = italic_m / 2 + 2 and scale parameter S=(EW−ρ⁢W)−1𝑆superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑊𝜌𝑊1S=(E_{W}-\rho W)^{-1}italic_S = ( italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_ρ italic_W ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ controls the degree of spatial dependence. The prior is thereby loosely centered around a conditionally auto-regressive model (CAR; Besag,, 1974) that encourages strong association between neighboring teeth.

2.3.4 Prior for the density of the errors

To estimate the unknown baseline density f𝑓fitalic_f, we assign a Dirichlet process (DP) mixture prior of Gaussians. The Dirichlet process (DP; Ferguson,, 1973), D⁢P⁢(γ,G0)𝐷𝑃𝛾subscript𝐺0DP(\gamma,G_{0})italic_D italic_P ( italic_γ , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), is a probability measure on probability measures, where γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0italic_γ > 0 is the concentration parameter and G0subscript𝐺0G_{0}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the base probability measure. A DP mixture prior of Gaussians on f𝑓fitalic_f posits that

ϵi⁢j∣μi⁢j,σi⁢j2conditionalsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\epsilon_{ij}\mid\mu_{ij},\sigma^{2}_{ij}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼𝒩⁢(μi⁢j,σi⁢j2),similar-toabsent𝒩subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(\mu_{ij},\sigma^{2}_{ij}),∼ caligraphic_N ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (μi⁢j,σi⁢j2)∣Gconditionalsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖𝑗𝐺\displaystyle(\mu_{ij},\sigma^{2}_{ij})\mid G( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∣ italic_G ∼G,similar-toabsent𝐺\displaystyle\sim G,∼ italic_G , G𝐺\displaystyle Gitalic_G ∼D⁢P⁢(γ,G0).similar-toabsent𝐷𝑃𝛾subscript𝐺0\displaystyle\sim DP(\gamma,G_{0}).∼ italic_D italic_P ( italic_γ , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

The stick-breaking construction by Sethuraman, (1994) allows us to express G𝐺Gitalic_G as

G⁢(μ,σ2)𝐺𝜇superscript𝜎2\displaystyle G(\mu,\sigma^{2})italic_G ( italic_μ , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) =∑h=1∞πh⁢δ(ϕh,sh2)⁢(μ,σ2),absentsuperscriptsubscriptℎ1subscript𝜋ℎsubscript𝛿subscriptitalic-ϕℎsubscriptsuperscript𝑠2ℎ𝜇superscript𝜎2\displaystyle=\sum_{h=1}^{\infty}\pi_{h}\delta_{(\phi_{h},\,s^{2}_{h})}(\mu,% \sigma^{2}),= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_μ , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (πh)h=1∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜋ℎℎ1\displaystyle\left(\pi_{h}\right)_{h=1}^{\infty}( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼GEM⁢(γ),similar-toabsentGEM𝛾\displaystyle\sim\text{GEM}(\gamma),∼ GEM ( italic_γ ) , (ϕh,sh2)h=1∞superscriptsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕℎsubscriptsuperscript𝑠2ℎℎ1\displaystyle\left(\phi_{h},s^{2}_{h}\right)_{h=1}^{\infty}( italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼G0,similar-toabsentsubscript𝐺0\displaystyle\sim G_{0},∼ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

where GEM stands for Griffiths, Engen and McCloskey (see Pitman, (2002) for details) and δ(ϕ,s2)⁢(⋅)subscript𝛿italic-ϕsuperscript𝑠2⋅\delta_{(\phi,\,s^{2})}(\cdot)italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ϕ , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) is the Dirac measure at (ϕ,s2)italic-ϕsuperscript𝑠2(\phi,s^{2})( italic_ϕ , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

We choose a conjugate normal inverse-gamma 𝒩⁢ℐ⁢𝒢⁢(μϵ,νϵ,aϵ,λϵ)𝒩ℐ𝒢subscript𝜇italic-ϵsubscript𝜈italic-ϵsubscript𝑎italic-ϵsubscript𝜆italic-ϵ\mathcal{NIG}(\mu_{\epsilon},\nu_{\epsilon},a_{\epsilon},\lambda_{\epsilon})caligraphic_N caligraphic_I caligraphic_G ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) as the base distribution G0subscript𝐺0G_{0}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and put a gamma prior 𝒢⁢(aγ,λγ)𝒢subscript𝑎𝛾subscript𝜆𝛾\mathcal{G}(a_{\gamma},\lambda_{\gamma})caligraphic_G ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) on γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, in the light of Escobar and West, (1995). Posterior sampling is carried out using a blocked Gibbs sampler (Ishwaran and James,, 2001) that uses a finite truncation for the number of mixture components upto a large number H𝐻Hitalic_H, and is known to exhibit scalability and good mixing.

2.3.5 Prior for the Dirichlet parameters of the relative disease increment times

We impose independent gamma priors on 𝒢⁢(aα,λα)𝒢subscript𝑎𝛼subscript𝜆𝛼\mathcal{G}(a_{\alpha},\lambda_{\alpha})caligraphic_G ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) on αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, k=1,2,…,K𝑘12…𝐾k=1,2,\ldots,Kitalic_k = 1 , 2 , … , italic_K, and perform posterior sampling using a random walk Metropolis within Gibbs algorithm, tuned for an acceptance ratio of 0.2−0.40.20.40.2-0.40.2 - 0.4.

2.4 Estimation of state occupation and transition probabilities

The SOP and TP for each disease state (along with their credible intervals) can be estimated using Monte Carlo posterior samples. We will employ the joint distribution of 𝑹i⁢jsubscript𝑹𝑖𝑗\bm{R}_{ij}bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the marginal distribution of log ⁢Ti⁢jlog subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗\text{log }T_{ij}log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which can be specified as a mixture of Gaussians using (2.5),

log ⁢Ti⁢j∼∑h=1∞πh⁢𝒩⁢(g⁢(𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢𝜷)+ϕh,σb,j2+sh2)similar-tolog subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptℎ1subscript𝜋ℎ𝒩𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top𝜷subscriptitalic-ϕℎsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑏𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑠2ℎ\text{log }T_{ij}\sim\sum_{h=1}^{\infty}\pi_{h}\,\mathcal{N}\left(\,g(\bm{x}_{% ij}^{\top}\,\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$})+\phi_{h},\ \sigma^{2}_{b,j}+s^{2}_{h}\,\right)log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N ( italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) + italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (2.10)

where σb,j2=𝒛j⊤⁢Σb⁢𝒛jsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑏𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒛𝑗topsubscriptΣ𝑏subscript𝒛𝑗\sigma^{2}_{b,j}=\bm{z}_{j}^{\top}\Sigma_{b}\,\bm{z}_{j}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,   𝒛j⊤superscriptsubscript𝒛𝑗top\bm{z}_{j}^{\top}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denoting the j𝑗jitalic_jth row of 𝒁𝒁\bm{Z}bold_italic_Z. Corresponding to each posterior sample of our model parameters and each tooth of each subject, we draw B𝐵Bitalic_B independent samples from the joint distribution of 𝑹𝑹\bm{R}bold_italic_R and that from the marginal distribution of T𝑇Titalic_T using (2.10), details of which are outlined in Section D of the Supplement. Henceforth, we drop the subscripts i⁢j𝑖𝑗ijitalic_i italic_j for clarity of notation. Let {Ti′,𝑹i′:i′=1,2,…,B}conditional-setsubscript𝑇superscript𝑖′subscript𝑹superscript𝑖′superscript𝑖′12…𝐵\{T_{i^{\prime}},\bm{R}_{i^{\prime}}:i^{\prime}=1,2,\ldots,B\}{ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 , 2 , … , italic_B } denote the Monte Carlo samples. Letting Ri′(0)=0subscriptsuperscript𝑅0superscript𝑖′0R^{(0)}_{i^{\prime}}=0italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, Ri′(K+1)=∞subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝐾1superscript𝑖′R^{(K+1)}_{i^{\prime}}=\inftyitalic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_K + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∞, we define indicator functions ηk⁢(t;T,𝑹)=𝟙⁢(T⁢∑l=0kR(l)≤t<T⁢∑l=0k+1R(l))subscript𝜂𝑘𝑡𝑇𝑹1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝑘superscript𝑅𝑙𝑡𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝑘1superscript𝑅𝑙\eta_{k}(t\,;\,T,\bm{R})=\mathds{1}\big{(}T\sum_{l=0}^{k}{R^{\,(l)}}\leq t<T% \sum_{l=0}^{k+1}R^{\,(l)}\big{)}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ; italic_T , bold_italic_R ) = blackboard_1 ( italic_T ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_t < italic_T ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) corresponding to the SOPs using (2.1) and (2.4) for each state k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}italic_k ∈ caligraphic_K, and estimate the probabilities with their Monte Carlo averages, p^k⁢(t)=(1/B)⁢∑i′=1Bηk⁢(t;Ti′,𝑹i′)subscript^𝑝𝑘𝑡1𝐵superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑖′1𝐵subscript𝜂𝑘𝑡subscript𝑇superscript𝑖′subscript𝑹superscript𝑖′\widehat{p}_{k}(t)=(1/B)\ \sum_{i^{\prime}=1}^{B}\eta_{k}(t\,;\,T_{i^{\prime}}% ,\bm{R}_{i^{\prime}})over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = ( 1 / italic_B ) ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ; italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The TPs defined as a conditional probability can similarly be estimated by the Monte Carlo method, p^r⁢s⁢(u,t)=∑i′=1Bηs⁢(t+u;Ti′,𝑹i′)⁢ηr⁢(u;Ti′,𝑹i′)/∑i′=1Bηr⁢(u;Ti′,𝑹i′)subscript^𝑝𝑟𝑠𝑢𝑡superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑖′1𝐵subscript𝜂𝑠𝑡𝑢subscript𝑇superscript𝑖′subscript𝑹superscript𝑖′subscript𝜂𝑟𝑢subscript𝑇superscript𝑖′subscript𝑹superscript𝑖′superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑖′1𝐵subscript𝜂𝑟𝑢subscript𝑇superscript𝑖′subscript𝑹superscript𝑖′\widehat{p}_{rs}(u,t)={\sum_{i^{\prime}=1}^{B}\eta_{s}(t+u\,;\,T_{i^{\prime}},% \bm{R}_{i^{\prime}})\ \eta_{r}(u\,;\,T_{i^{\prime}},\bm{R}_{i^{\prime}})}\bigg% {/}{\sum_{i^{\prime}=1}^{B}\eta_{r}(u\,;\,T_{i^{\prime}},\bm{R}_{i^{\prime}})}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u , italic_t ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t + italic_u ; italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ; italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ; italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), r≤s𝑟𝑠r\leq sitalic_r ≤ italic_s, r,s∈𝒦𝑟𝑠𝒦r,s\in\mathcal{K}italic_r , italic_s ∈ caligraphic_K.

3 Application: GAAD data

In this section, we illustrate our methodology via application to the GAAD dataset. Progression of PD is usually assessed via clinical attachment level (CAL; Bandyopadhyay and Canale,, 2016), defined as the distance (in mm whole numbers) down a tooth’s root that is no longer attached to the surrounding bone by the periodontal ligament, and recorded at six pre-specified tooth sites for each of the 28282828 teeth, excluding the four third molars. Following the definition (Wiebe and Putnins,, 2000) of chronic periodontitis severity, our tooth-level PD status comprises average CAL (avCAL) at the corresponding tooth-sites, and categorized into 4444 states: 00 denotes slight PD (avCAL ∈[0,2)absent02\in[0,2)∈ [ 0 , 2 ) mm), 1111 denotes moderate PD (avCAL ∈[2,5)absent25\in[2,5)∈ [ 2 , 5 ) mm), 2222 denotes severe PD (avCAL ≥5absent5\geq 5≥ 5 mm) and 3333 denotes missing tooth (avCAL is unavailable, due to past PD). The natural history of chronic PD can be viewed as a staged progressive disease process, from gingivitis to periodontitis characterized by irreversible pathological changes (Mdala et al.,, 2014), as shown in Figure 2.1. In cross-sectional studies like GAAD, the true inspection time for each tooth should be calculated from the adult tooth emergence time, which is typically unavailable. In lieu of this, we approximate the tooth inspection time for all subjects by taking the difference between the subject’s age (recorded at clinic visit) and the permanent dentition times of US adults published by the American Dental Association, (2022). The data includes n=288𝑛288n=288italic_n = 288 subjects with m=28𝑚28m=28italic_m = 28 teeth for each subject, 46%percent4646\%46 % of which are in state 00, 19%percent1919\%19 % in state 1111, 2%percent22\%2 % in state 2 and the remaining 32%percent3232\%32 % in state 3333. The subjects have a mean age of 55555555 years, ranging from 26 to 87 years. Around 76%percent7676\%76 % of the subjects are female, 68%percent6868\%68 % are categorized as obese (with a BMI ≥\geq≥ 30), 31%percent3131\%31 % are smokers, and 59%percent5959\%59 % have uncontrolled HbA1c levels. BMI, being a continuous covariate is standardized to have mean 00 and variance 1111.

We considered six competing models during data fitting, which differ in terms of their specifications for the monotone link basis, random effects, and distribution of random errors:

  1. 1.

    S-GP-DP: Spatial random effects with constrained GP basis for the link function, and DP mixture prior on the error density – our proposed model.

  2. 2.

    S-BP-DP: Spatial random effects with Bernstein polynomial (BP) basis for the link function and DP mixture prior on the error density.

  3. 3.

    S-GP-N: Spatial random effects with constrained GP basis for the link function, and normal density for errors.

  4. 4.

    S-BP-N: Spatial random effects with BP basis for the link function, and normal density for errors.

  5. 5.

    S-lin-DP: Linear model (identity link) with spatial random effects, and DP mixture prior on the error density.

  6. 6.

    NS-GP-DP: Non-spatial random effects at the subject-level (bi⁢1=…=bi⁢m=bisubscript𝑏𝑖1…subscript𝑏𝑖𝑚subscript𝑏𝑖b_{i1}=\ldots=b_{im}=b_{i}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = … = italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) with constrained GP basis for the link function, and DP mixture prior on the error density.

For our analysis, we set σβ2=100superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛽2100\sigma_{\beta}^{2}=100italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 100, though any arbitrary positive value can be used since β~~𝛽\tilde{\beta}over~ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG is scaled by its norm. For the link function, we use default choices of ν=0.75𝜈0.75\nu=0.75italic_ν = 0.75, with ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ chosen such that the correlation at a maximum covariate separation is 0.050.050.050.05 (Ray et al.,, 2020), and set η=100,aξ=0.01formulae-sequence𝜂100subscript𝑎𝜉0.01\eta=100,a_{\xi}=0.01italic_η = 100 , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.01 and bξ=0.01subscript𝑏𝜉0.01b_{\xi}=0.01italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.01. The degree of spatial dependence is set to ρ=0.9𝜌0.9\rho=0.9italic_ρ = 0.9 in the prior on ΣbsubscriptΣ𝑏\Sigma_{b}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For the DP mixture, we set H=10𝐻10H=10italic_H = 10, μϵ=0subscript𝜇italic-ϵ0\mu_{\epsilon}=0italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, νϵ=1subscript𝜈italic-ϵ1\nu_{\epsilon}=1italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, and choose aϵsubscript𝑎italic-ϵa_{\epsilon}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, bϵsubscript𝑏italic-ϵb_{\epsilon}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to yield a prior mean and variance of sh2superscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ2s_{h}^{2}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as 0.10.10.10.1 and 10101010, respectively. The parameters in the gamma prior on γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ is chosen to have mean 1111 and variance 10101010. Since information on the state transition times from the observed data is weak, we use a weakly informative gamma prior on 𝜶𝜶\alphabold_italic_α with mean 1111 and variance 100100100100. More details on the choice hyperparameters for each prior are provided in Section E.1 of the Supplement.

We generated posterior MCMC samples of size 70,000 iterations with a burn-in of 20,000 and collected every 50th sample to thin the chain. Posterior convergence was assessed using trace plots and the Gelman-Rubin statistic R^^𝑅\hat{R}over^ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG. For model selection tools, we considered the Watanabe-Akaike information criterion (WAIC), and the leave-one-out cross-validation (LOO-IC) using Pareto-smoothed importance sampling available in R package loo, and enlist them in Table 3.1. Models with smaller WAIC and LOO-IC values suggest a better fit to the observed data. For all models except (5), the optimal number of basis functions L𝐿Litalic_L was set to 30303030, chosen by minimizing WAIC as L𝐿Litalic_L varied from 10 to 45 in increments of 5; details are provided in Section E.2 of the Supplement.

The non-spatial model having the highest value of both WAIC and LOO-IC validates the necessity of incorporating the intraoral spatial dependencies between the teeth. Among the spatial models, the 3 models having a DP mixture prior on the error density have lower WAIC and LOO-IC, warranting the improved flexibility of DP over normal errors. This is further supported by the larger variability observed in the boxplots of model-based residuals for the models with a normal errors, compared to the DP errors; see Section E.3 of the Supplement. The models with constrained GP basis for the monotone link show better predictive performance compared to the corresponding ones with BP basis. Clearly, our proposed S-GP-DP model outperforms all its competitors.

3.1 Estimation of fixed effects and spatial dependence

Posterior estimates and 95%percent9595\%95 % credible intervals (CIs) of the regression parameters obtained from fitting the six competing models are presented in Figure 1(a). The CI for upper jaw (maxilla) excluded 00, and the posterior estimates were negative with highest magnitude for all six models, indicating that this covariate has the strongest influence on the index. Consequently, the index and hence the survival time, for a maxillary tooth is lower than that for a mandibular tooth. This is in tune with findings revealing higher loss and extraction of maxillary tooth, than mandibular, due to PD (Chraibi et al.,, 2023). Strong evidence of a higher index is observed in females compared to males from the S-GP-DP, S-BP-N and NS-GP-DP models, resonating with higher prevalence of chronic PD in males (Ioannidou,, 2017). This association, however, lacks significance (though positive) in the other models. Smoking is revealed to negatively impact the index in all models, leading to reduced survival, thereby corroborating with published literature (Zee,, 2009), with significant impact in the S-GP-DP and NS-GP-DP models. BMI and glycemic levels do not seem to significantly affect the index, with the exception of a strong negative impact of HbA1c in the NS-GP-DP model.

Figure 1(b) plots the link functions estimated from the models, along with their 95%percent9595\%95 % CIs. The range of the link functions estimated by the three models having constrained GP basis are similar. The spatial models with BP basis and normal errors have a higher range, while that with DP mixture errors has a very low range. This is in alignment with the performance of these models in our simulation studies (see Section 4 for details). The estimates exp⁡(g^⁢(βl^)−g^⁢(0))^𝑔^subscript𝛽𝑙^𝑔0\exp(\hat{g}(\hat{\beta_{l}})-\hat{g}(0))roman_exp ( over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( over^ start_ARG italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) - over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( 0 ) ) for the significant predictors i.e.gender, smoking and maxilla from our S-GP-DP model indicate females have approximately 2.22.22.22.2 times the survival time of males, smokers have about 0.650.650.650.65 times that of non-smokers, and maxillary teeth exhibit a survival time of 0.30.30.30.3 times that of mandibular teeth. The S-GP-N and S-BP-N models show similar estimates. These estimates from the S-BP-DP model are close to 1111 for all predictors, as evident from the low range of its estimated link function. The NS-GP-DP model additionally identifies glycemic level as a significant predictor, showing that a high glycemic level reduces survival time to 0.56 times that of a low level.

Heatmaps of the posterior estimate of the precision matrix ΩbsubscriptΩ𝑏\Omega_{b}roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the random effects in the five spatial models are illustrated in Figure 1(c). Strong correlations are seen between first molars (teeth 2 and 13), which are mirror images in opposite maxillary quadrants, consistent with clinical findings which highlight that molars and premolars generally exhibit higher levels of PD (Kindler et al.,, 2018). The matrices are mostly concentrated along their tridiagonal, confirming the neighborhood association depicted in Figure 2.1 and suggests that spatial dependence weakens considerably beyond the immediate neighboring tooth.

3.2 Estimation of state occupation and transition probabilities

To illustrate the use of our model to probe the association between a covariate and the state occupation and transition probabilities of teeth, we arbitrarily consider a female smoker aged 56 years (median), with a BMI of 35.33 (mean) and uncontrolled HbA1c. Figure 3.2 plots the posterior mean and 95%percent9595\%95 % CI of the SOPs over the years 10–80, and TPs for the next 10 years (with the baseline age set to the median of 56 years), for the maxillary (upper jaw) and mandibular (lower jaw) second molar (teeth numbers 1 and 28, respectively) of this subject, based on 10,000 Monte Carlo samples. On the overall, our model indicates that maxillary location negatively affects tooth survival. The SOPs for state 00 decreases while that for state 3333 increase over time, with the mandibular molar having higher (lower) SOP for state 0 (3), than that of the maxillary counterpart, as one would naturally expect. Consequently, intersecting trajectories for the SOPs of states 1111 and 2222 was observed, initially showing an increasing trend for both jaws before decreasing, with the change-point occurring at a higher age for mandible than that for maxilla.

To collectively summarize the combined effect of all the covariates on these probabilities, Figure 3.2 plots the posterior mean and 95%percent9595\%95 % CIs of the SOPs over the years 10–80, and TPs for the next 10 years, corresponding to the minimum, median and maximum value of the estimated index u^i⁢j=𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢^⁢𝜷subscript^𝑢𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top^absent𝜷\hat{u}_{ij}=\bm{x}_{ij}^{\top}\hat{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}over^ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β, where 𝜷^^𝜷\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_β end_ARG denotes the posterior mean of 𝜷𝜷\betabold_italic_β. The baseline age for the TPs is again set to 56 years (median). Quite intuitively, patterns similar to Figure 3.2 are observed. Decreasing (increasing) trend in the SOP of states 0 (state 3) is observed, with a higher probability at any given time for a higher index, with intersecting trajectories for states 1 and 2. A lower index corresponds to an elevated chance of transitioning to a higher state of the disease at any given time. We further note that the estimated probability of occupying state 2222 and that of transitioning from state 1111 to state 2222 is quite low compared to the other SOPs and TPs respectively. This can be partially attributed to the fact that only 2%percent22\%2 % of the observations in our data occupied state 2222.

4 Simulation studies

In this section, we conduct simulations using synthetic data to (a) investigate the frequentist finite sample properties, and (b) the effect of model misspecification in recovering the regression parameters 𝜷𝜷\betabold_italic_β, and the link function g𝑔gitalic_g, while using our proposed model. Henceforth, we refer to them as Simulations 1 and 2, respectively, and compare the performances of models (1)–(4) outlined in Section 3.

At the onset, we outline the data generating process followed in the two simulation settings. Our data generation mimics a practical setting as observed in the GAAD study. We consider p=3𝑝3p=3italic_p = 3 covariates, the highest disease state K=3𝐾3K=3italic_K = 3, m=10𝑚10m=10italic_m = 10 teeth for every subject, and vary the sample size as n=50,100,300𝑛50100300n=50,100,300italic_n = 50 , 100 , 300 and 500500500500. The data generation steps are as follows:


Step 1. Let 𝒙~i⁢j=(x~i⁢j(1),x~i⁢j(2),x~i⁢j(3))subscript~𝒙𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑗1superscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑗2superscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑗3\widetilde{\bm{x}}_{ij}=(\widetilde{x}_{ij}^{\,(1)},\widetilde{x}_{ij}^{\,(2)}% ,\widetilde{x}_{ij}^{\,(3)})over~ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( over~ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , over~ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , over~ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 3 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) denote the vector of covariates, for every i𝑖iitalic_i and j𝑗jitalic_j. Here x~i⁢j(1)superscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑗1\widetilde{x}_{ij}^{\,(1)}over~ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and x~i⁢j(2)superscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑗2\widetilde{x}_{ij}^{\,(2)}over~ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote continuous and discrete subject level covariates respectively, which are generated by drawing x~i(1)∼Unif⁢(−5,5)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖1Unif55\widetilde{x}_{i}^{\,(1)}\sim\text{Unif}(-5,5)over~ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ Unif ( - 5 , 5 ), x~i(2)∼Bin⁢(1,0.5)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖2Bin10.5\widetilde{x}_{i}^{\,(2)}\sim\text{Bin}(1,0.5)over~ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ Bin ( 1 , 0.5 ) and setting x~i⁢j(1)=x~i(1)superscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑗1superscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖1\widetilde{x}_{ij}^{\,(1)}=\widetilde{x}_{i}^{\,(1)}over~ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over~ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and x~i⁢j(2)=x~i(2)superscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑗2superscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖2\widetilde{x}_{ij}^{\,(2)}=\widetilde{x}_{i}^{\,(2)}over~ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over~ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all j𝑗jitalic_j. Also, x~i⁢j(3)superscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑗3\widetilde{x}_{ij}^{(3)}over~ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 3 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT takes the value 1111 for j>m/2𝑗𝑚2j>m/2italic_j > italic_m / 2 and 00 otherwise (mimicking jaw indicator). The re-scaled covariates are obtained as 𝒙i⁢j=𝒙~i⁢j/max⁡‖𝒙~i⁢j‖subscript𝒙𝑖𝑗subscript~𝒙𝑖𝑗normsubscript~𝒙𝑖𝑗\bm{x}_{ij}=\widetilde{\bm{x}}_{ij}/\max\|\widetilde{\bm{x}}_{ij}\|bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over~ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / roman_max ∥ over~ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥.

Step 2. The true regression parameters are set at 𝜷0=~⁢𝜷0/‖~⁢𝜷0‖superscript𝜷0~absentsuperscript𝜷0norm~absentsuperscript𝜷0\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}^{0}=\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}^{0}\,/\,\|% \widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}^{0}\|bold_italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ∥ over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ with ~⁢𝜷0=(−1,1,−1)~absentsuperscript𝜷0111\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}^{0}=(-1,1,-1)over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( - 1 , 1 , - 1 ).

Step 3. Generate the random effects 𝒃i=(bi⁢1,…,bi⁢m/2)⊤∼𝒩⁢(0,Σb)subscript𝒃𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖1…subscript𝑏𝑖𝑚2topsimilar-to𝒩0subscriptΣ𝑏\bm{b}_{i}=(b_{i1},\ldots,b_{i\,m/2})^{\top}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\Sigma_{b})bold_italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where Σb=0.12⁢(EW−0.9⁢W)−1subscriptΣ𝑏superscript0.12superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑊0.9𝑊1\Sigma_{b}=0.1^{2}(E_{W}-0.9W)^{-1}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 0.9 italic_W ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT i.e.from a parametric CAR density, with EWsubscript𝐸𝑊E_{W}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and W𝑊Witalic_W constructed according to Section 2.3.3. Set bi⁢j′=bi⁢jsubscript𝑏𝑖superscript𝑗′subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗b_{ij^{\prime}}=b_{ij}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for j′=m−j+1superscript𝑗′𝑚𝑗1j^{\prime}=m-j+1italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_m - italic_j + 1, j=1,…,m/2𝑗1…𝑚2j=1,\ldots,m/2italic_j = 1 , … , italic_m / 2,

Step 4. The random errors ϵi⁢jsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗\epsilon_{ij}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under the two simulation settings are generated from a discrete mixture of Gaussians, and a mixture of Gaussian and t𝑡titalic_t densities respectively, as follows: (a) Simulation 1: ϵi⁢j∼(1/3)⁢𝒩⁢(−0.5,0.12)+(1/3)⁢𝒩⁢(0,0.12)+(1/3)⁢𝒩⁢(0.5,0.12)similar-tosubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗13𝒩0.5superscript0.1213𝒩0superscript0.1213𝒩0.5superscript0.12\epsilon_{ij}\sim(1/3)\,\mathcal{N}(-0.5,0.1^{2})+(1/3)\,\mathcal{N}(0,0.1^{2}% )+(1/3)\,\mathcal{N}(0.5,0.1^{2})italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ ( 1 / 3 ) caligraphic_N ( - 0.5 , 0.1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + ( 1 / 3 ) caligraphic_N ( 0 , 0.1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + ( 1 / 3 ) caligraphic_N ( 0.5 , 0.1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ); (b) Simulation 2: ϵi⁢j∼0.9⁢𝒩⁢(0,0.12)+0.1⁢t3similar-tosubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗0.9𝒩0superscript0.120.1subscript𝑡3\epsilon_{ij}\sim 0.9\,\mathcal{N}(0,0.1^{2})+0.1\,t_{3}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ 0.9 caligraphic_N ( 0 , 0.1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + 0.1 italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Here, t3subscript𝑡3t_{3}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes a t𝑡titalic_t density with 3333 degrees of freedom. The t3subscript𝑡3t_{3}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT distribution introduces heavy tails and different error behavior than a simpler discrete mixture of Gaussians.

Step 5. We consider the following true monotone link functions :

g10⁢(x)subscriptsuperscript𝑔01𝑥\displaystyle g^{0}_{1}(x)italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) =c1⋅{Φ⁢((x+1)/2− 0.50.2)−Φ⁢(− 0.5/0.2)}⁢𝟙[−1,1]⁢(x)absent⋅subscript𝑐1Φ𝑥120.50.2Φ0.50.2subscript111𝑥\displaystyle=c_{1}\cdot\left\{\Phi\left(\frac{(x+1)/2\ -\ 0.5}{0.2}\right)-% \Phi\left({-\ 0.5}/{0.2}\right)\right\}\mathds{1}_{[-1,1]}(x)= italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ { roman_Φ ( divide start_ARG ( italic_x + 1 ) / 2 - 0.5 end_ARG start_ARG 0.2 end_ARG ) - roman_Φ ( - 0.5 / 0.2 ) } blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ - 1 , 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x )
g20⁢(x)subscriptsuperscript𝑔02𝑥\displaystyle g^{0}_{2}(x)italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) =c2⋅{(x+12)2+(x+12)3}⁢𝟙[−1,1]⁢(x)absent⋅subscript𝑐2superscript𝑥122superscript𝑥123subscript111𝑥\displaystyle=c_{2}\cdot\bigg{\{}\left(\frac{x+1}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{x+% 1}{2}\right)^{3}\bigg{\}}\mathds{1}_{[-1,1]}(x)= italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ { ( divide start_ARG italic_x + 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( divide start_ARG italic_x + 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ - 1 , 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x )

where Φ⁢(⋅)Φ⋅\Phi(\cdot)roman_Φ ( ⋅ ) denotes the CDF of a standard Gaussian distribution and the constants c1subscript𝑐1c_{1}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, c2subscript𝑐2c_{2}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are so chosen that the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is fixed at 5555. Note that g10superscriptsubscript𝑔10g_{1}^{0}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is both convex and concave with an inflection point at 0, while g20superscriptsubscript𝑔20g_{2}^{0}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is strictly convex. They allow us to assess the model’s ability to capture diverse relationships between the predictors and the response.

Step 6. The true time to the missing tooth (denoting the highest state) Ti⁢jsubscript𝑇𝑖𝑗T_{ij}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are generated using (2.2). The relative time increments of the disease states are generated as 𝑹i⁢j∼Dir⁢(3,4,2)similar-tosubscript𝑹𝑖𝑗Dir342\bm{R}_{ij}\sim\text{Dir}(3,4,2)bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ Dir ( 3 , 4 , 2 ) and the random inspection times Ci⁢jsubscript𝐶𝑖𝑗C_{ij}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are generated from 𝒢⁢(1,0.2)𝒢10.2\mathcal{G}(1,0.2)caligraphic_G ( 1 , 0.2 ) and 𝒢⁢(1,0.5)𝒢10.5\mathcal{G}(1,0.5)caligraphic_G ( 1 , 0.5 ) for the two link functions, respectively. Time to the kt⁢hsuperscript𝑘𝑡ℎk^{th}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT disease state are obtained using (2.3). The parameters of the generating distribution of Ci⁢jsubscript𝐶𝑖𝑗C_{ij}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are so chosen to avoid large discrepancies between the proportion of individuals having disease status 00 and those having status K𝐾Kitalic_K.
