Step 7. The disease states at their inspection times Si⁢j⁢(Ci⁢j)subscript𝑆𝑖𝑗subscript𝐶𝑖𝑗S_{ij}(C_{ij})italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are determined using (2.4).

For all competing models, we conduct MCMC sampling for 7,000 iterations and discard the first 5,000 as burn-in. Posterior estimates are summarized over 100100100100 simulation replicates. Estimation performance is compared using mean squared error (MSE), relative bias (RB) and coverage probability (CP) of the estimated 95%percent9595\%95 % CIs for each component of 𝜷𝜷\betabold_italic_β and mean integrated squared error (MISE) for the link functions, respectively. Let β^jsubscript^𝛽𝑗\hat{\beta}_{j}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the posterior mean of βjsubscript𝛽𝑗\beta_{j}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Component-wise MSE and RB are calculated as

MSE⁢(β^j)=(β^j−βj0)2,RB⁢(β^j)=(β^j−βj0)/βj0.formulae-sequenceMSEsubscript^𝛽𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝛽𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝛽0𝑗2RBsubscript^𝛽𝑗subscript^𝛽𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝛽0𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝛽0𝑗\text{MSE}(\hat{\beta}_{j})=(\hat{\beta}_{j}-\beta^{0}_{j})^{2},\qquad\text{RB% }(\hat{\beta}_{j})=(\hat{\beta}_{j}-\beta^{0}_{j})/\beta^{0}_{j}.MSE ( over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , RB ( over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

For estimating the two link functions g10subscriptsuperscript𝑔01g^{0}_{1}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and g20subscriptsuperscript𝑔02g^{0}_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we consider 100100100100 equidistant grid points {y1,y2,…,y100}subscript𝑦1subscript𝑦2…subscript𝑦100\{y_{1},y_{2},\ldots,y_{100}\}{ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 100 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } in [−1,1]11[-1,1][ - 1 , 1 ], and let g^j⁢(yi)subscript^𝑔𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖\hat{g}_{j}(y_{i})over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) denote the j𝑗jitalic_jth estimated link function at the i𝑖iitalic_ith grid point. The MISE of g^jsubscript^𝑔𝑗\hat{g}_{j}over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is calculated as

MISE⁢(g^j)=1100⁢∑i=1100{g^j⁢(yi)−gj 0⁢(yi)}2.MISEsubscript^𝑔𝑗1100superscriptsubscript𝑖1100superscriptsubscript^𝑔𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑗 0subscript𝑦𝑖2\text{MISE}(\hat{g}_{j})=\frac{1}{100}\sum_{i=1}^{100}\left\{\hat{g}_{j}(y_{i}% )-g_{j}^{\,0}(y_{i})\right\}^{2}.MISE ( over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 100 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT { over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Results considering the true link function as g10subscriptsuperscript𝑔01g^{0}_{1}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are presented here, while those from g20subscriptsuperscript𝑔02g^{0}_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are deferred to Section F of the Supplement. We provide boxplots of the MSE, RB and MISE and barplots of the CP across the 100 replicates over increasing n𝑛nitalic_n under Simulations 1 and 2 in Figures 4.1 and 4.2 respectively.

Simulation 1: When the model is correctly specified, the S-GP-DP and S-GP-N models yield an overall superior estimation performance than the models with BP basis. Decreasing trends in the boxplots of MSE, RB and MISE with increasing sample sizes imply posterior estimates from the models with constrained GP basis are consistent. The desired 95%percent9595\%95 % coverage is attained by each β^jsubscript^𝛽𝑗\hat{\beta}_{j}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for both small and large sample sizes. While S-BP-N shows a poor performance in terms of all aforementioned metrics, the S-BP-DP model shows an overall worse performance.

Simulation 2: When the model is misspecified, the S-GP-DP and S-GP-N models are again seen to yield an overall superior estimation performance, compared to the S-BP-DP and S-BP-N. The GP models deliver satisfactory estimation performances in terms of MSE, RB and MISE. The GP models attain the desired 95%percent9595\%95 % coverage across all sample sizes. Though S-BP-N attains the nominal CP, the coverage of S-BP-DP falls sharply with increasing sample size (1%percent11\%1 % for n=500𝑛500n=500italic_n = 500). The regression parameter estimates from the S-BP-N appear to be robust for all sample sizes, however, the estimation of the link function worsens acutely with increase in the sample size. Estimation of the link function and the regression parameters are observed to be poor under the S-BP-DP model. To summarize, estimates from the GP models are found to be robust under model misspecification. While the estimation of the link function under the S-BP-N model suffers for large sample sizes, the S-BP-DP model delivers poor performances across all sample sizes.

The poor performance of the BP-DP model can be attributed to the global nature of the BP basis, where the identifiability constraint (g⁢(−1)=0𝑔10g(-1)=0italic_g ( - 1 ) = 0) impacts the overall flexibility of the link function estimation, unlike the local basis used in the GP method. Additionally, the BP-DP model faces the challenge of simultaneously estimating both the link function and the error density, whereas the BP-N model benefits from a fixed Gaussian assumption for the error distribution, enabling better recovery of the link function.

5 Conclusions

Motivated by a cross-sectional PD study, we introduce a novel framework for estimating a clinically interpretable tooth-level disease risk index within a multistate model, accounting for spatially-referenced current status data. Our approach leverages advanced posterior sampling techniques, such as elliptical slice sampling and circulant embedding, to address computational challenges. Applied to the GAAD data, our model confirms higher PD risk among males and smokers (Genco and Borgnakke,, 2013), but, consistent with our preliminary results, does not reveal a significant association between HbA1c levels and PD progression.

We estimate transition probabilities under the assumption that future transitions depend only on the current state. While incorporating sojourn times (i.e.the duration a tooth remains in a particular state before transitioning) could be considered, this is challenging under the current status framework. Our model adopts a forward tracking structure, reflecting the progressive nature of PD (Coventry et al.,, 2000), but could be extended to allow reversible transitions, as relevant in other diseases. We also assume independent censoring; relaxing this to allow for informative inspection times, (e.g., via copula models (Zhao et al.,, 2015)), is complex and presents a separate scope of future study. Recent advances in single index models using neural networks (Bietti et al.,, 2022) do not enforce monotonicity of the link function, which is key for clinical interpretability. Integrating machine learning tools to estimate monotone SIMs is a promising future direction. Moreover, while advanced areal spatial models, such as the Directed Acyclic Graph Auto-Regressive model (Datta et al.,, 2019) exist, we opt for a simpler inverse-Wishart approach to avoid complicating our existing framework on monotone link function and error density estimation. This aims to mitigate potential mixing issues that may arise from introducing additional complexities to the model.

Finally, our analysis of the GAAD dataset reveals its limitations, including only four subject-level covariates and a relatively small sample size, in light of recently available databases of larger dimensions. Extending our approach to larger cross-sectional studies like NHANES (CDC,, 1996) will require significant computational enhancements, but the availability of abundant covariates in such databases could facilitate techniques such as variable selection within the single index framework to construct an interpretable index.

Acknowledgements

The authors acknowledge the Center for Oral Health Research at the Medical University of South Carolina for providing the motivating GAAD dataset, and partial funding support from NIH/NIDCR grants R21DE031879, and R01DE031134.

Data Availability

The motivating GAAD data that support the findings of this study are available at the GitHub repository, das-snigdha/BayesSPMSM. Computing code is also available on this repository.

  • Ray et al., (2020) Ray, P., Pati, D., and Bhattacharya, A. (2020). Efficient Bayesian shape-restricted function estimation with constrained Gaussian process priors. Statistics and Computing, 30:839 – 853.
  • Reich and Bandyopadhyay, (2010) Reich, B. and Bandyopadhyay, D. (2010). A latent factor model for spatial data with informative missingness. Annals of Applied Statistics, 4(1):439–459.
  • Sethuraman, (1994) Sethuraman, J. (1994). A Constructive Definition of Dirichlet Priors. Statistica Sinica, 4:639–650.
  • Turnbull, (1976) Turnbull, B. W. (1976). The empirical distribution function with arbitrarily grouped, censored and truncated data. Journal of the Royal Statistical Society. Series B (Methodological), 38(3):290–295.
  • van den Hout, (2016) van den Hout, A. (2016). Multi-State Survival Models for Interval-Censored Data. Chapman and Hall/CRC, 1st edition.
  • Wan, (2016) Wan, L. (2016). Continuous Time Multi-State Models for Interval Censored Data. PhD thesis, University of Kentucky.
  • Wang and Ghosh, (2012) Wang, J. and Ghosh, S. K. (2012). Shape Restricted Nonparametric Regression with Bernstein Polynomials. Computational Statistics and Data Analysis, 56(9):2729–2741.
  • Wang and Li, (2008) Wang, X. and Li, F. (2008). Isotonic smoothing spline regression. J. Comput. Graph. Stat., 17:21–37.
  • Wiebe and Putnins, (2000) Wiebe, C. B. and Putnins, E. E. (2000). The periodontal disease classification system of the American Academy of Periodontology – An update. Journal of the Canadian Dental Association, 66(11):594–599.
  • Wood and Chan, (1994) Wood, A. T. and Chan, G. (1994). Simulation of stationary Gaussian processes in [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d}[ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics, 3(4):409–432.
  • Zee, (2009) Zee, K.-Y. (2009). Smoking and Periodontal Disease. Australian Dental Journal, 54:S44–S50.
  • Zhao et al., (2015) Zhao, S., Hu, T., Ma, L., Wang, P., and Sun, J. (2015). Regression analysis of informative current status data with the additive hazards model. Lifetime Data Analysis, 21:241–258.

Supplementary Materials

This supplement contains a preliminary analysis of the GAAD data, proof of results on model identifiability, blocked full conditional posterior distribution of parameters, details on estimation of state occupation and transition probabilities, additional details on the GAAD data analysis, and additional simulation results. Code for implementing our model is available at the GitHub repository, das-snigdha/BayesSPMSM.

Appendix A GAAD data: some specifics and preliminary analysis

For an initial preliminary analysis, we converted the multistate responses of the GAAD data (see Section 3 of the main document for details) into interval-censored, corresponding to tooth occupying state 3333, i.e. tooth loss.

Figure A.1 presents the nonparametric Turnbull estimates (Turnbull,, 1976) of tooth-level survival curves, grouped by smoking status and HbA1c, revealing worse survival for smokers, but overlapping curves for the HbA1c levels. Furthermore, a fitted accelerated failure time (AFT) model (with Weibull errors) incorporating squared BMI and interactions between smoking, gender and HbA1c along with the main covariates, reveals smoking, jaw indicator and smoking×\times×gender interaction to be strongly significant predictors. Additionally, squared BMI and smoking×\times×HbA1c interaction were marginally significant. This provides an indication for the presence of non-linearity in covariates. The absence of a clear unified strategy that accommodates non-linearity and interactions to yield a concise and interpretable single-number summary motivates us to develop a holistic AFT regression approach, incorporating monotone single index model within a progressive multistate modeling framework that facilitates efficient risk quantification on the entire tooth decay process via automatic consideration of non-linear main effects and higher order interactions through a scalar single index.

Appendix B Identifiability of parameters

In the following, we provide the proofs of Propositions 2.1 and 2.2, which establishes the identifiability of the variance components and fixed effects parameters of our proposed model.

B.1 Proof of Proposition 2.1

We start by recalling from Section 2.2 of the main document, that our AFT model can be concisely written as

𝒚i=𝒁⁢𝒃i+𝒈i+ϵi,i=1,2,…,nformulae-sequencesubscript𝒚𝑖𝒁subscript𝒃𝑖subscript𝒈𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖𝑖12…𝑛\bm{y}_{i}=\bm{Z}\bm{b}_{i}+\mbox{\boldmath$g$}_{i}+\mbox{\boldmath$\epsilon$}% _{i},\quad\quad i=1,2,\ldots,nbold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_Z bold_italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i = 1 , 2 , … , italic_n

where 𝒁=[𝕀m/2⁢𝕀~m/2]⊤𝒁superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝕀𝑚2subscript~𝕀𝑚2top\bm{Z}=[\mathbb{I}_{m/2}\ \tilde{\mathbb{I}}_{m/2}]^{\top}bold_italic_Z = [ blackboard_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG blackboard_I end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and 𝕀m/2subscript𝕀𝑚2\mathbb{I}_{m/2}blackboard_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝕀~m/2subscript~𝕀𝑚2\tilde{\mathbb{I}}_{m/2}over~ start_ARG blackboard_I end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote m/2×m/2𝑚2𝑚2m/2\times m/2italic_m / 2 × italic_m / 2 identity matrix and anti-diagonal matrix with unit entries, respectively. The covariance matrix of 𝒚isubscript𝒚𝑖\bm{y}_{i}bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is then given by Σy=𝒁⁢Σb⁢𝒁⊤+ΣϵsubscriptΣ𝑦𝒁subscriptΣ𝑏superscript𝒁topsubscriptΣitalic-ϵ\Sigma_{y}=\bm{Z}\Sigma_{b}\bm{Z}^{\top}+\Sigma_{\epsilon}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_Z roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Σϵ=σϵ2⁢𝕀msubscriptΣitalic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ2subscript𝕀𝑚\Sigma_{\epsilon}=\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}\mathbb{I}_{m}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, σϵ2>0superscriptsubscript𝜎italic-ϵ20\sigma_{\epsilon}^{2}>0italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 denotes the common variance of the errors ϵi⁢jsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗\epsilon_{ij}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ΣbsubscriptΣ𝑏\Sigma_{b}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the covariance matrix of the random effects 𝒃isubscript𝒃𝑖\bm{b}_{i}bold_italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Suppose Σ⁢(𝜽)Σ𝜽\Sigma(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$})roman_Σ ( bold_italic_θ ) denotes a matrix parameterized by a vector 𝜽𝜽\thetabold_italic_θ in the space Θ={𝜽:Σ⁢(𝜽)⁢ is symmetric and positive definite}Θconditional-set𝜽Σ𝜽 is symmetric and positive definite\Theta=\{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}:\Sigma(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$})\text{ is % symmetric and positive definite}\}roman_Θ = { bold_italic_θ : roman_Σ ( bold_italic_θ ) is symmetric and positive definite }. Cov⁢(yi⁢j,yi⁢j′)=(Σy)j⁢j′={σb,j⁢j′,if ⁢1≤j<j′≤m2;j′≠m−j+1σb,(m−j+1)⁢(m−j′+1),if ⁢m2<j<j′≤m;j′≠m−j+1σb,j⁢(m−j′+1),if ⁢1≤j≤m2<j′≤mσb,j2,if ⁢j′=m−j+1Covsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝑗′subscriptsubscriptΣ𝑦𝑗superscript𝑗′casessubscript𝜎𝑏𝑗superscript𝑗′formulae-sequenceif 1𝑗superscript𝑗′𝑚2superscript𝑗′𝑚𝑗1subscript𝜎𝑏𝑚𝑗1𝑚superscript𝑗′1formulae-sequenceif 𝑚2𝑗superscript𝑗′𝑚superscript𝑗′𝑚𝑗1subscript𝜎𝑏𝑗𝑚superscript𝑗′1if 1𝑗𝑚2superscript𝑗′𝑚superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑏𝑗2if superscript𝑗′𝑚𝑗1\text{Cov}(y_{ij},y_{ij^{\prime}})=(\Sigma_{y})_{jj^{\prime}}=\begin{cases}% \sigma_{b,jj^{\prime}},&\text{if }1\leq j<j^{\prime}\leq\frac{m}{2};\ j^{% \prime}\neq m-j+1\\ \sigma_{b,(m-j+1)(m-j^{\prime}+1)},&\text{if }\frac{m}{2}<j<j^{\prime}\leq m;% \ j^{\prime}\neq m-j+1\\ \sigma_{b,j(m-j^{\prime}+1)},&\text{if }1\leq j\leq\frac{m}{2}<j^{\prime}\leq m% \\ \sigma_{b,j}^{2},&\text{if }j^{\prime}=m-j+1\end{cases}Cov ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b , italic_j italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL if 1 ≤ italic_j < italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ; italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ italic_m - italic_j + 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b , ( italic_m - italic_j + 1 ) ( italic_m - italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL if divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG < italic_j < italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_m ; Then, Σy⁢(𝜽b,𝜽ϵ)=Σy⁢(𝜽b′,𝜽ϵ′)subscriptΣ𝑦subscript𝜽𝑏subscript𝜽italic-ϵsubscriptΣ𝑦subscriptsuperscript𝜽′𝑏subscriptsuperscript𝜽′italic-ϵ\Sigma_{y}(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{b},\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{\epsilon})=% \Sigma_{y}(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}^{\prime}_{b},\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}^{% \prime}_{\epsilon})roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) implies 𝜽b=𝜽b′subscript𝜽𝑏subscriptsuperscript𝜽′𝑏\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{b}=\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}^{\prime}_{b}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using (B.2) and 𝜽ϵ=𝜽ϵ′subscript𝜽italic-ϵsubscriptsuperscript𝜽′italic-ϵ\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{\epsilon}=\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}^{\prime}_{\epsilon}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using (B.1).

B.2 Proof of Proposition 2.2

We begin by noting that our observed current status data is represented as {𝒙i⁢j,Ci⁢j,Si⁢j⁢(Ci⁢j)}subscript𝒙𝑖𝑗subscript𝐶𝑖𝑗subscript𝑆𝑖𝑗subscript𝐶𝑖𝑗\{\bm{x}_{ij},C_{ij},S_{ij}(C_{ij})\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) }, where 𝒙i⁢jsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗\bm{x}_{ij}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the vector of covariates, Ci⁢jsubscript𝐶𝑖𝑗C_{ij}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the random inspection times and Si⁢j⁢(Ci⁢j)subscript𝑆𝑖𝑗subscript𝐶𝑖𝑗S_{ij}(C_{ij})italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) denotes the disease state occupation at the inspection time. Clearly, Si⁢j⁢(Ci⁢j)subscript𝑆𝑖𝑗subscript𝐶𝑖𝑗S_{ij}(C_{ij})italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) takes values in 𝒦={0,1,…,K}𝒦01…𝐾\mathcal{K}=\{0,1,\ldots,K\}caligraphic_K = { 0 , 1 , … , italic_K } and let 𝒄i=(ci⁢1,…,ci⁢m)subscript𝒄𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖1…subscript𝑐𝑖𝑚\bm{c}_{i}=(c_{i1},\ldots,c_{im})bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) denote the observed values of the inspection times. Under the assumption of independent censoring, the likelihood function for our model is given by

L⁢(𝜽,𝜼)𝐿𝜽𝜼\displaystyle L(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$},\mbox{\boldmath$\eta$})italic_L ( bold_italic_θ , bold_italic_η ) =∏i=1np𝑪⁢(ci⁢1,…,ci⁢m)⁢p𝑺⁢(si⁢1⁢(ci⁢1),si⁢2⁢(ci⁢2),…,si⁢m⁢(ci⁢m)∣𝜽,𝜶,𝝍)absentsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑝𝑪subscript𝑐𝑖1…subscript𝑐𝑖𝑚subscript𝑝𝑺subscript𝑠𝑖1subscript𝑐𝑖1subscript𝑠𝑖2subscript𝑐𝑖2…conditionalsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑚subscript𝑐𝑖𝑚𝜽𝜶𝝍\displaystyle=\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{\bm{C}}(c_{i1},\ldots,c_{im})\,p_{\bm{S}}\left% (s_{i1}(c_{i1}),s_{i2}(c_{i2}),\ldots,s_{im}(c_{im})\mid\mbox{\boldmath$\theta% $},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$},\mbox{\boldmath$\psi$}\right)\,= ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , … , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∣ bold_italic_θ , bold_italic_α , bold_italic_ψ )
∝∏i=1np𝑺⁢(𝒔i∣𝜽,𝜶,𝝍),proportional-toabsentsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑝𝑺conditionalsubscript𝒔𝑖𝜽𝜶𝝍\displaystyle\propto\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{\bm{S}}\left(\bm{s}_{i}\mid\mbox{% \boldmath$\theta$},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$},\mbox{\boldmath$\psi$}\right)\,,∝ ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ bold_italic_θ , bold_italic_α , bold_italic_ψ ) ,

Note that 𝜽∈Θ={(g,𝜷):g∈𝒞ℳ,𝜷∈𝒮p−1}𝜽Θconditional-set𝑔𝜷formulae-sequence𝑔subscript𝒞ℳ𝜷subscript𝒮𝑝1\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in\Theta=\{(g,\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}):g\in\mathcal{C% }_{\mathcal{M}},\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}\in\mathcal{S}_{p-1}\}bold_italic_θ ∈ roman_Θ = { ( italic_g , bold_italic_β ) : italic_g ∈ caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_β ∈ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and 𝜶∈(0,∞)K𝜶superscript0𝐾\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$}\in(0,\infty)^{K}bold_italic_α ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Under independent censoring, p𝑪subscript𝑝𝑪p_{\bm{C}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is free of the parameters involved in the multistate model and hence the censoring distribution does not contribute to the likelihood function of our model parameters.

Let 𝜶1,𝜶2∈(0,∞)Ksubscript𝜶1subscript𝜶2superscript0𝐾\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$}_{1},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$}_{2}\in(0,\infty)^{K}bold_italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ ( 0 , ∞ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝜽1,𝜽2∈Θsubscript𝜽1subscript𝜽2Θ\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{1},\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{2}\in\Theta\,bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ roman_Θ such that

p𝑺⁢(𝒔∣𝜽1,𝜶1,𝝍)=p𝑺⁢(𝒔∣𝜽2,𝜶2,𝝍).subscript𝑝𝑺conditional𝒔subscript𝜽1subscript𝜶1𝝍subscript𝑝𝑺conditional𝒔subscript𝜽2subscript𝜶2𝝍p_{\bm{S}}(\bm{s}\mid\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{1},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$}_{1}% ,\mbox{\boldmath$\psi$})=p_{\bm{S}}(\bm{s}\mid\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{2},% \mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$}_{2},\mbox{\boldmath$\psi$})\,.italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ∣ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_ψ ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ∣ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_ψ ) . (B.3)

To demonstrate identifiability of the fixed effects parameters, it suffices to show that (B.3) implies 𝜽1=𝜽2subscript𝜽1subscript𝜽2\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{1}=\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{2}bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all 𝜽1,𝜽2∈Θsubscript𝜽1subscript𝜽2Θ\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{1},\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{2}\in\Thetabold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ roman_Θ. Note that (B.3) implies

pSj⁢(sj∣𝜽1,𝜶1,𝝍)=pSj⁢(sj∣𝜽2,𝜶2,𝝍),for all ⁢j=1,2,…,m,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝subscript𝑆𝑗conditionalsubscript𝑠𝑗subscript𝜽1subscript𝜶1𝝍subscript𝑝subscript𝑆𝑗conditionalsubscript𝑠𝑗subscript𝜽2subscript𝜶2𝝍for all 𝑗12…𝑚p_{S_{j}}(s_{j}\mid\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{1},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$}_{1},% \mbox{\boldmath$\psi$})=p_{S_{j}}(s_{j}\mid\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{2},\mbox{% \boldmath$\alpha$}_{2},\mbox{\boldmath$\psi$}),\quad\text{for all }j=1,2,% \ldots,m,italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_ψ ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_ψ ) , for all italic_j = 1 , 2 , … , italic_m , (B.4)

where, pSj(⋅∣𝜽,𝜶,𝝍)p_{S_{j}}(\cdot\mid\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$},\mbox{% \boldmath$\psi$})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ∣ bold_italic_θ , bold_italic_α , bold_italic_ψ ) denotes the marginal distribution of Si⁢j⁢(ci⁢j)subscript𝑆𝑖𝑗subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗S_{ij}(c_{ij})italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the disease state occupied by tooth j𝑗jitalic_j at its observed inspection time ci⁢jsubscript𝑐𝑖𝑗c_{ij}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for each subject i=1,2,…⁢n𝑖12…𝑛i=1,2,\ldots nitalic_i = 1 , 2 , … italic_n. Thus, it suffices to work with the disease state of one tooth, say Si⁢1subscript𝑆𝑖1S_{i1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at its inspection time ci⁢1subscript𝑐𝑖1c_{i1}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any subject i𝑖iitalic_i. Let σb,12=(Σb)11superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑏12subscriptsubscriptΣ𝑏11\sigma_{b,1}^{2}=(\Sigma_{b})_{11}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 11 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the marginal variance of the random effect for this tooth. Henceforth, we shall drop the subscripts (i,1)𝑖1(i,1)( italic_i , 1 ) from the random variables for clarity of notation.

From equation (2.4) of the main document:

S⁢(c)=kifT⁢∑l=0kR(l)≤c<T⁢∑l=0k+1R(l),k=0,1,…,K,formulae-sequenceformulae-sequence𝑆𝑐𝑘if𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝑘superscript𝑅𝑙𝑐𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝑘1superscript𝑅𝑙𝑘01…𝐾S(c)=k\quad\textrm{if}\quad{T}\sum_{l=0}^{k}{R^{\,(l)}}\leq{c}<{T}\sum_{l=0}^{% k+1}{R^{\,(l)}},\quad k=0,1,\ldots,K\,,italic_S ( italic_c ) = italic_k if italic_T ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_c < italic_T ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_k = 0 , 1 , … , italic_K , (B.5)

where R(0):=0assignsuperscript𝑅00R^{\,(0)}:=0italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := 0 and R(K+1):=∞assignsuperscript𝑅𝐾1R^{\,(K+1)}:=\inftyitalic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_K + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := ∞. From (B.5), we observe that the marginal distribution of S⁢(c)𝑆𝑐S(c)italic_S ( italic_c ) is a categorical distribution on 𝒦={0,1,…,K}𝒦01…𝐾\mathcal{K}=\{0,1,\ldots,K\}caligraphic_K = { 0 , 1 , … , italic_K } with probabilities {pk⁢(𝜽,𝜶,𝝍)=P𝜽,𝜶,𝝍⁢(S⁢(c)=k):k∈𝒦}conditional-setsubscript𝑝𝑘𝜽𝜶𝝍subscript𝑃𝜽𝜶𝝍𝑆𝑐𝑘𝑘𝒦\{p_{k}(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$},\mbox{\boldmath$\psi% $})=P_{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$},\mbox{\boldmath$\psi$% }}\left(S(c)=k\right):k\in\mathcal{K}\}{ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ , bold_italic_α , bold_italic_ψ ) = italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ , bold_italic_α , bold_italic_ψ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ( italic_c ) = italic_k ) : italic_k ∈ caligraphic_K }. (B.4) implies

pk⁢(𝜽1,𝜶1,𝝍)=pk⁢(𝜽2,𝜶2,𝝍),for all ⁢k∈𝒦.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝜽1subscript𝜶1𝝍subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝜽2subscript𝜶2𝝍for all 𝑘𝒦p_{k}(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{1},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$}_{1},\mbox{% \boldmath$\psi$})=p_{k}(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{2},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$}_% {2},\mbox{\boldmath$\psi$}),\quad\text{for all }k\in\mathcal{K}\,.italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_ψ ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_ψ ) , for all italic_k ∈ caligraphic_K . (B.6)

Observe that for k=K𝑘𝐾k=Kitalic_k = italic_K, we have S⁢(c)=K𝑆𝑐𝐾S(c)=Kitalic_S ( italic_c ) = italic_K if T≤c𝑇𝑐{T}\leq{c}italic_T ≤ italic_c, since 𝑹𝑹\bm{R}bold_italic_R follows a Dirichlet distribution and ∑l=0KR(l)=1superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝐾superscript𝑅𝑙1\sum_{l=0}^{K}{R^{\,(l)}}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 with probability 1. Therefore,

pK⁢(𝜽,𝜶,𝝍)subscript𝑝𝐾𝜽𝜶𝝍\displaystyle p_{K}(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$},\mbox{% \boldmath$\psi$})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ , bold_italic_α , bold_italic_ψ ) =P𝜽,𝜶,𝝍⁢(T≤c)=F⁢(log ⁢c−b−g⁢(𝒙⊤⁢𝜷))absentsubscript𝑃𝜽𝜶𝝍𝑇𝑐𝐹log 𝑐𝑏𝑔superscript𝒙top𝜷\displaystyle=P_{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$},\mbox{% \boldmath$\psi$}}\left(T\leq c\right)=F\left(\text{log }c-b-g(\bm{x}^{\top}% \mbox{\boldmath$\beta$})\right)= italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_θ , bold_italic_α , bold_italic_ψ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_T ≤ italic_c ) = italic_F ( log italic_c - italic_b - italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) ) (B.7)

Letting 𝕊K−1subscript𝕊𝐾1\mathbb{S}_{K-1}blackboard_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote a K𝐾Kitalic_K-dimensional simplex and writing pK⁢(𝜽)subscript𝑝𝐾𝜽p_{K}(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ ) explicitly, we have

pK⁢(𝜽,𝜶,𝝍)subscript𝑝𝐾𝜽𝜶𝝍\displaystyle p_{K}(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$},\mbox{% \boldmath$\psi$})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ , bold_italic_α , bold_italic_ψ ) =P⁢(S⁢(c)=K∣𝜽,𝜶,𝝍)absent𝑃𝑆𝑐conditional𝐾𝜽𝜶𝝍\displaystyle=P\left(S(c)=K\mid\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha% $},\mbox{\boldmath$\psi$}\right)= italic_P ( italic_S ( italic_c ) = italic_K ∣ bold_italic_θ , bold_italic_α , bold_italic_ψ )

=∫ℝF⁢(log ⁢c−b−g⁢(𝒙⊤⁢𝜷))⁢1σb⁢ϕ⁢(bσb)⁢{∫𝕊K−1f𝑹⁢(𝑹∣𝜶)⁢𝑑𝑹}⁢𝑑babsentsubscriptℝ𝐹log 𝑐𝑏𝑔superscript𝒙top𝜷1subscript𝜎𝑏italic-ϕ𝑏subscript𝜎𝑏subscriptsubscript𝕊𝐾1subscript𝑓𝑹conditional𝑹𝜶differential-d𝑹differential-d𝑏\displaystyle=\int_{\mathbb{R}}F\left(\text{log }c-b-g(\bm{x}^{\top}\mbox{% \boldmath$\beta$})\right)\frac{1}{\sigma_{b}}\phi\left(\frac{b}{\sigma_{b}}% \right)\left\{\int_{\mathbb{S}_{K-1}}f_{\bm{R}}\left(\bm{R}\mid\mbox{\boldmath% $\alpha$}\right)\,d\bm{R}\right\}\,db= ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( log italic_c - italic_b - italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) ) divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_ϕ ( divide start_ARG italic_b end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) { ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_R ∣ bold_italic_α ) italic_d bold_italic_R } italic_d italic_b
=∫ℝF⁢(log ⁢c−b−g⁢(𝒙⊤⁢𝜷))⁢1σb⁢ϕ⁢(bσb)⁢𝑑b,absentsubscriptℝ𝐹log 𝑐𝑏𝑔superscript𝒙top𝜷1subscript𝜎𝑏italic-ϕ𝑏subscript𝜎𝑏differential-d𝑏\displaystyle=\int_{\mathbb{R}}F\left(\text{log }c-b-g(\bm{x}^{\top}\mbox{% \boldmath$\beta$})\right)\frac{1}{\sigma_{b}}\,\phi\left(\frac{b}{\sigma_{b}}% \right)\ db\,,= ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( log italic_c - italic_b - italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) ) divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_ϕ ( divide start_ARG italic_b end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_d italic_b , (B.8)

where ϕ⁢(⋅)italic-ϕ⋅\phi(\cdot)italic_ϕ ( ⋅ ) and f𝑹(⋅∣𝜶)f_{\bm{R}}(\cdot\mid\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ∣ bold_italic_α ) denote the probability density functions of a standard Gaussian distribution and a Dirichlet distribution with parameters 𝜶𝜶\alphabold_italic_α, respectively.

Next, define a function

h⁢(z)=∫ℝF⁢(log ⁢C−b−z)⁢1σb⁢ϕ⁢(b1σb)⁢𝑑b1.ℎ𝑧subscriptℝ𝐹log 𝐶𝑏𝑧1subscript𝜎𝑏italic-ϕsubscript𝑏1subscript𝜎𝑏differential-dsubscript𝑏1h(z)=\int_{\mathbb{R}}F\left(\text{log }C-b-z\right)\frac{1}{\sigma_{b}}\,\phi% \left(\frac{b_{1}}{\sigma_{b}}\right)\ db_{1}\,.italic_h ( italic_z ) = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( log italic_C - italic_b - italic_z ) divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_ϕ ( divide start_ARG italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_d italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

We claim that h⁢(z)ℎ𝑧h(z)italic_h ( italic_z ) is a strictly decreasing function of z𝑧zitalic_z. As a proof, we first note that h⁢(z)ℎ𝑧h(z)italic_h ( italic_z ) is non-increasing in z𝑧zitalic_z, since F⁢(log ⁢c−b−z)𝐹log 𝑐𝑏𝑧F(\text{log }c-b-z)italic_F ( log italic_c - italic_b - italic_z ) is a non-increasing function of z𝑧zitalic_z, for all b∈ℝ𝑏ℝb\in\mathbb{R}italic_b ∈ blackboard_R. The proof follows by contradiction. Let, if possible, h⁢(z1)=h⁢(z2)ℎsubscript𝑧1ℎsubscript𝑧2h(z_{1})=h(z_{2})italic_h ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_h ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for z1<z2subscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2z_{1}<z_{2}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let

and z∗=log ⁢c−(z1+z2)/2superscript𝑧log 𝑐subscript𝑧1subscript𝑧22z^{*}=\text{log }c-(z_{1}+z_{2})/2italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = log italic_c - ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / 2, and note that

ψ⁢(z∗−y)𝜓superscript𝑧𝑦\displaystyle\psi(z^{*}-y)italic_ψ ( italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_y ) =−ψ⁢(z∗+y),y∈ℝformulae-sequenceabsent𝜓superscript𝑧𝑦𝑦ℝ\displaystyle=-\,\psi(z^{*}+y),\quad y\in\mathbb{R}= - italic_ψ ( italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y ) , italic_y ∈ blackboard_R (B.9)

Then,

0=h⁢(z1)−h⁢(z2)=∫ℝF⁢(log ⁢c−b1−z1)⁢1σb⁢ϕ⁢(b1σb)⁢𝑑b1−∫ℝF⁢(log ⁢c−b1−z2)⁢1σb⁢ϕ⁢(b1σb)⁢𝑑b1=∫ℝF⁢(y)⁢1σb⁢[ϕ⁢(y+z1−log ⁢cσb)−ϕ⁢(y+z2−log ⁢cσb)]⁢𝑑y=∫ℝF⁢(y)⁢ψ⁢(y)⁢𝑑y=∫−∞z∗F⁢(y)⁢ψ⁢(y)⁢𝑑y+∫z∗∞F⁢(y)⁢ψ⁢(y)⁢𝑑y=∫−∞z∗{F⁢(y)−F⁢(2⁢z∗−y)}⁢ψ⁢(y)⁢𝑑y,since ⁢ψ⁢(2⁢z∗−y)=−ψ⁢(y)=∫0∞{F⁢(z∗+y)−F⁢(z∗−y)}⁢ψ⁢(z∗+y)⁢𝑑y,using ⁢(⁢B.9⁢).\begin{split}0&=h(z_{1})-h(z_{2})\\ &=\int_{\mathbb{R}}F\left(\text{log }c-b_{1}-z_{1}\right)\frac{1}{\sigma_{b}}% \phi\left(\frac{b_{1}}{\sigma_{b}}\right)\ db_{1}-\int_{\mathbb{R}}F\left(% \text{log }c-b_{1}-z_{2}\right)\frac{1}{\sigma_{b}}\phi\left(\frac{b_{1}}{% \sigma_{b}}\right)\ db_{1}\\ &=\int_{\mathbb{R}}F\left(y\right)\frac{1}{\sigma_{b}}\left[\phi\left(\frac{y+% z_{1}-\text{log }c}{\sigma_{b}}\right)-\phi\left(\frac{y+z_{2}-\text{log }c}{% \sigma_{b}}\right)\right]dy\\ &=\int_{\mathbb{R}}F(y)\ \psi(y)\ dy\\ &=\int_{-\infty}^{z^{*}}F(y)\ \psi(y)\ dy\ +\ \int_{z^{*}}^{\infty}F(y)\ \psi(% y)\ dy\\ &=\int_{-\infty}^{z^{*}}\{F(y)-F(2z^{*}-y)\}\,\psi(y)\,dy,\quad\qquad\text{% since }\psi(2z^{*}-y)=-\psi(y)\\ &=\int_{0}^{\infty}\{F(z^{*}+y)-F(z^{*}-y)\}\ \psi(z^{*}+y)\ dy,\qquad\quad% \text{using }\eqref{eq:psi_1}\,.\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL = italic_h ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( log italic_c - italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_ϕ ( divide start_ARG italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_d italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_y ) divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG [ italic_ϕ ( divide start_ARG italic_y + italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - Using (B.10), (B.11) implies F⁢(z∗+y)=F⁢(z∗−y)𝐹superscript𝑧𝑦𝐹superscript𝑧𝑦F(z^{*}+y)=F(z^{*}-y)italic_F ( italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y ) = italic_F ( italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_y ), for all y>0𝑦0y>0italic_y > 0, which shows that F𝐹Fitalic_F is symmetric about z∗superscript𝑧z^{*}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and contradicts the fact that F𝐹Fitalic_F is a CDF.

Finally, (B.6) implies pK⁢(𝜽1,𝜶1,𝝍)=pK⁢(𝜽2,𝜶2,𝝍)subscript𝑝𝐾subscript𝜽1subscript𝜶1𝝍subscript𝑝𝐾subscript𝜽2subscript𝜶2𝝍p_{K}(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{1},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$}_{1},\mbox{% \boldmath$\psi$})=p_{K}(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}_{2},\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$}_% {2},\mbox{\boldmath$\psi$})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_ψ ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_ψ ), which is equivalent to h⁢(g1⁢(𝒙⊤⁢𝜷1))=h⁢(g2⁢(𝒙⊤⁢𝜷2))ℎsubscript𝑔1superscript𝒙topsubscript𝜷1ℎsubscript𝑔2superscript𝒙topsubscript𝜷2h(g_{1}(\bm{x}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}_{1}))=h(g_{2}(\bm{x}^{\top}\mbox{% \boldmath$\beta$}_{2}))\,italic_h ( italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = italic_h ( italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ). By invertibility of strictly monotone functions, we have g1⁢(𝒙⊤⁢𝜷1)=g2⁢(𝒙⊤⁢𝜷2)subscript𝑔1superscript𝒙topsubscript𝜷1subscript𝑔2superscript𝒙topsubscript𝜷2g_{1}(\bm{x}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}_{1})=g_{2}(\bm{x}^{\top}\mbox{% \boldmath$\beta$}_{2})italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which further implies g1=g2subscript𝑔1subscript𝑔2g_{1}=g_{2}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝜷1=𝜷2subscript𝜷1subscript𝜷2\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}_{1}=\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}_{2}bold_italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, by Theorem 1 from Lin and Kulasekera, (2007).

Appendix C Posterior Computation

This section enlists detailed derivations of the blocked full conditional distributions of the parameters and the latent variables of our model, along with their posterior sampling schemes. Recall from Section 2.3.4 of the main document that a Dirichlet process (DP) mixture prior of Gaussians on the baseline density f𝑓fitalic_f of the errors posits that

ϵi⁢j∣μi⁢j,σi⁢j2conditionalsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\epsilon_{ij}\mid\mu_{ij},\sigma^{2}_{ij}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼𝒩⁢(μi⁢j,σi⁢j2),similar-toabsent𝒩subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(\mu_{ij},\sigma^{2}_{ij}),∼ caligraphic_N ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (μi⁢j,σi⁢j2)∣Gconditionalsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖𝑗𝐺\displaystyle(\mu_{ij},\sigma^{2}_{ij})\mid G( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∣ italic_G ∼G,similar-toabsent𝐺\displaystyle\sim G,∼ italic_G , G𝐺\displaystyle Gitalic_G ∼D⁢P⁢(γ,G0).similar-toabsent𝐷𝑃𝛾subscript𝐺0\displaystyle\sim DP(\gamma,G_{0}).∼ italic_D italic_P ( italic_γ , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (C.1)

Using the atoms (μi⁢j,σi⁢j2)subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖𝑗(\mu_{ij},\sigma^{2}_{ij})( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of the DP mixture prior of Gaussians on the density of the random errors, we can express our AFT model given in equation (2.2) of the main document as,

log ⁢Ti⁢j=g⁢(𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢𝜷)+bi⁢j+μi⁢j+σi⁢j⁢ϵ~i⁢j,ϵ~i⁢j∼𝒩⁢(0,1),formulae-sequencelog subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top𝜷subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗subscript𝜎𝑖𝑗subscript~italic-ϵ𝑖𝑗similar-tosubscript~italic-ϵ𝑖𝑗𝒩01\text{log }T_{ij}=g(\bm{x}_{ij}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$})+b_{ij}+\mu_{ij}% +\sigma_{ij}\tilde{\epsilon}_{ij}\ ,\quad\tilde{\epsilon}_{ij}\sim\mathcal{N}(% 0,1),log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over~ start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , 1 ) ,

where g⁢(𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢𝜷)≈∑l=0Lξl⁢ψl⁢(𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢𝜷)𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top𝜷superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝐿subscript𝜉𝑙subscript𝜓𝑙superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top𝜷g(\bm{x}_{ij}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$})\approx\sum_{l=0}^{L}\xi_{l}\psi_{% l}(\bm{x}_{ij}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$})italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) ≈ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) using equation (2.7) of the main document. The subscripts i𝑖iitalic_i and j𝑗jitalic_j denote the subjects and teeth of each subject respectively in all successive subsections, i=1,2,…,n𝑖12…𝑛i=1,2,\ldots,nitalic_i = 1 , 2 , … , italic_n, j=1,2,…,m𝑗12…𝑚j=1,2,\ldots,mitalic_j = 1 , 2 , … , italic_m.

C.1 Regression parameters

Define

ui⁢j=log ⁢Ti⁢j−bi⁢j−μi⁢j,for each ⁢i,j.subscript𝑢𝑖𝑗log subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗for each 𝑖𝑗u_{ij}=\text{log }T_{ij}-b_{ij}-\mu_{ij},\quad\text{for each }i,j.italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , for each italic_i , italic_j . (C.2)

The conditional posterior of ~⁢𝜷~absent𝜷\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β is given by, p⁢(~⁢𝜷∣…)∝𝒩⁢(~⁢𝜷;0,σβ2)⁢Lβ⁢(~⁢𝜷),proportional-to𝑝conditional~absent𝜷…𝒩~absent𝜷0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛽2subscript𝐿𝛽~absent𝜷p\big{(}\,\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}\mid\ldots\,\big{)}\propto\ % \mathcal{N}\big{(}\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}\,;0,\sigma_{\beta}^{2}% \big{)}\ L_{\beta}\big{(}\,\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}\,\big{)},italic_p ( over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β ∣ … ) ∝ caligraphic_N ( over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β ; 0 , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β ) , where,

log ⁢Lβ⁢(~⁢𝜷)=−12⁢∑i,j1σi⁢j2⁢(ui⁢j−∑l=0Lξl⁢ψl⁢(𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢~⁢𝜷‖~⁢𝜷‖))2.log subscript𝐿𝛽~absent𝜷12subscript𝑖𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑗2superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝐿subscript𝜉𝑙subscript𝜓𝑙superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top~absent𝜷norm~absent𝜷2\text{log }L_{\beta}\big{(}\,\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}\,\big{)}=-% \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i,j}\frac{1}{\sigma_{ij}^{2}}\left(u_{ij}-\sum_{l=0}^{L}\xi_{% l}\,\psi_{l}\big{(}\bm{x}_{ij}^{\top}\frac{\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}% }{\|\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}\|}\big{)}\right)^{2}.log italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β ) = - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β end_ARG start_ARG ∥ over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β ∥ end_ARG ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

~⁢𝜷~absent𝜷\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β is sampled using the elliptical slice sampler (ESS, Murray et al.,, 2010), particularly suited for posterior sampling in models with multivariate Gaussian priors.

C.2 Monotone link function

Let ui⁢jsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑗u_{ij}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be defined as (C.2). Define ΨΨ\Psiroman_Ψ be an N×(L+1)𝑁𝐿1N\times(L+1)italic_N × ( italic_L + 1 ) matrix with elements Ψr⁢l=ψl⁢(𝜷T⁢𝒙r∗)/σr∗subscriptΨ𝑟𝑙subscript𝜓𝑙superscript𝜷𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝒙𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑟\Psi_{rl}=\psi_{l}(\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}^{T}\bm{x}^{*}_{r})/\sigma_{r}^{*}roman_Ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where N=m⁢n𝑁𝑚𝑛N=mnitalic_N = italic_m italic_n, and

(𝒙1∗,…,𝒙N∗)subscriptsuperscript𝒙1…subscriptsuperscript𝒙𝑁\displaystyle(\bm{x}^{*}_{1},\ldots,\bm{x}^{*}_{N})( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =(𝒙11,𝒙12,…,𝒙1⁢m,…,𝒙n⁢1,𝒙n⁢2,…,𝒙n⁢m)absentsubscript𝒙11subscript𝒙12…subscript𝒙1𝑚…subscript𝒙𝑛1subscript𝒙𝑛2…subscript𝒙𝑛𝑚\displaystyle=(\bm{x}_{11},\bm{x}_{12},\ldots,\bm{x}_{1m},\ldots,\bm{x}_{n1},% \bm{x}_{n2},\ldots,\bm{x}_{nm})= ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 11 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
(σ1∗,…,σN∗)subscriptsuperscript𝜎1…subscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑁\displaystyle(\sigma^{*}_{1},\ldots,\sigma^{*}_{N})( italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =(σ11,σ12,…,σ1⁢m,…,σn⁢1,σn⁢2,…,σn⁢m)absentsubscript𝜎11subscript𝜎12…subscript𝜎1𝑚…subscript𝜎𝑛1subscript𝜎𝑛2…subscript𝜎𝑛𝑚\displaystyle=(\sigma_{11},\sigma_{12},\ldots,\sigma_{1m},\ldots,\sigma_{n1},% \sigma_{n2},\ldots,\sigma_{nm})= ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 11 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

are simply the stacked covariates and error standard deviations over i𝑖iitalic_i and j𝑗jitalic_j. Similarly stack 𝒖=(u11,u12,…,u1⁢m,…,un⁢1,un⁢2,…,un⁢m)𝒖subscript𝑢11subscript𝑢12…subscript𝑢1𝑚…subscript𝑢𝑛1subscript𝑢𝑛2…subscript𝑢𝑛𝑚\bm{u}=(u_{11},u_{12},\ldots,u_{1m},\ldots,u_{n1},u_{n2},\ldots,u_{nm})bold_italic_u = ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 11 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

The coefficients 𝝃𝝃\xibold_italic_ξ in the basis expansion of the monotone link function given in equation (2.7) of the main document, have a zero-mean Gaussian prior with covariance matrix τ2⁢Ksuperscript𝜏2𝐾\tau^{2}Kitalic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K, where Ki⁢j=k⁢(ui−uj)subscript𝐾𝑖𝑗𝑘subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑢𝑗K_{ij}=k(u_{i}-u_{j})italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), k⁢(⋅)𝑘⋅k(\cdot)italic_k ( ⋅ ) is the stationary Matérn covariance kernel with smoothness parameter ν>0𝜈0\nu>0italic_ν > 0 and length-scale parameter ℓ>0ℓ0\ell>0roman_ℓ > 0. The most general definition of the Matérn covariance kernel is the following:

k⁢(r)=21−νΓ⁢(ν)⁢(2⁢ν⁢rℓ)ν⁢Kν⁢(2⁢ν⁢rℓ),𝑘𝑟superscript21𝜈Γ𝜈superscript2𝜈𝑟ℓ𝜈subscript𝐾𝜈2𝜈𝑟ℓk(r)=\frac{2^{1-\nu}}{\Gamma(\nu)}\left(\frac{\sqrt{2\nu}\,r}{\ell}\right)^{% \nu}K_{\nu}\left(\frac{\sqrt{2\nu}\,r}{\ell}\right),italic_k ( italic_r ) = divide start_ARG 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 - italic_ν end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_Γ ( italic_ν ) end_ARG ( divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 italic_ν end_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ν end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ν end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 italic_ν end_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG ) ,

where Kνsubscript𝐾𝜈K_{\nu}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ν end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the modified Bessel function of the second kind. The parameter τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ controls the prior signal to noise ratio. A non-informative inverse-gamma ℐ⁢𝒢⁢(aξ,bξ)ℐ𝒢subscript𝑎𝜉subscript𝑏𝜉\mathcal{IG}(a_{\xi},b_{\xi})caligraphic_I caligraphic_G ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) prior is placed on τ2superscript𝜏2\tau^{2}italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The conditional posterior of the parameters involving estimation of the monotone link function is given by,

p⁢(𝝃,τ∣…)∝(τ2)−(aξ+1)⁢e−bξ/τ2⁢(τ2)−(L+1)/2⁢e−𝝃⊤⁢K−1⁢𝝃/(2⁢τ2)⁢𝕁η⁢(𝝃)⁢e−‖𝒖−Ψ⁢𝝃‖2/2,proportional-to𝑝𝝃conditional𝜏…superscriptsuperscript𝜏2subscript𝑎𝜉1superscript𝑒subscript𝑏𝜉superscript𝜏2superscriptsuperscript𝜏2𝐿12superscript𝑒superscript𝝃topsuperscript𝐾1𝝃2superscript𝜏2subscript𝕁𝜂𝝃superscript𝑒superscriptnorm𝒖Ψ𝝃22\displaystyle p(\bm{\xi},\tau\mid\ldots)\propto(\tau^{2})^{-(a_{\xi}+1)}e^{-{b% _{\xi}}/\tau^{2}}(\tau^{2})^{-(L+1)/2}e^{\,-{\bm{\xi}}^{\top}K^{-1}{\bm{\xi}}% \,/\,(2\tau^{2})}\ \mathbb{J}_{\eta}(\bm{\xi})\ e^{\,-\|\bm{u}-\Psi{\bm{\xi}}% \|^{2}/2},italic_p ( bold_italic_ξ , italic_τ ∣ … ) ∝ ( italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_L + 1 ) / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_ξ / ( 2 italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_η end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ξ ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ∥ bold_italic_u - roman_Ψ bold_italic_ξ ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where 𝕁η⁢(𝝃)=∏l=0L(1+e−η⁢ξl)−1subscript𝕁𝜂𝝃superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑙0𝐿superscript1superscript𝑒𝜂subscript𝜉𝑙1\mathbb{J}_{\eta}(\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$})=\prod_{l=0}^{L}(1+e^{\,-\eta\,\xi_{l}% })^{-1}blackboard_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_η end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ξ ) = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_η italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The sampling algorithm proceeds as follows:

  1. 1.

    Update 𝝃𝝃\xibold_italic_ξ: The full conditional of 𝝃𝝃\xibold_italic_ξ is given by

    p⁢(𝝃∣…)∝𝒩⁢(𝝃;0,τ2⁢K)⁢Lξ⁢(𝝃),proportional-to𝑝conditional𝝃…𝒩𝝃0superscript𝜏2𝐾subscript𝐿𝜉𝝃p(\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$}\mid\ldots\,)\propto\ \mathcal{N}(\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$}% \,;0,\tau^{2}K)\ L_{\xi}(\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$}),italic_p ( bold_italic_ξ ∣ … ) ∝ caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_ξ ; 0 , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K ) italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ξ ) ,

    where Lξ⁢(𝝃)=e−‖𝒖−Ψ⁢𝝃‖2/2⁢𝕁η⁢(𝝃)subscript𝐿𝜉𝝃superscript𝑒superscriptnorm𝒖Ψ𝝃22subscript𝕁𝜂𝝃L_{\xi}(\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$})=e^{\,-\|\bm{u}-\Psi{\bm{\xi}}\|^{2}/2}\ \mathbb% {J}_{\eta}(\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$})italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ξ ) = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ∥ bold_italic_u - roman_Ψ bold_italic_ξ ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_η end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ξ ). Posterior samples of 𝝃𝝃\xibold_italic_ξ are obtained using the ESS scheme by Murray et al., (2010) by sampling a proposal from its prior 𝒩⁢(0,τ2⁢K)𝒩0superscript𝜏2𝐾\mathcal{N}(0,\tau^{2}K)caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K ) using the algorithm by Wood and Chan, (1994).

  2. 2.

    Update τ2superscript𝜏2\tau^{2}italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: The full conditional of τ2superscript𝜏2\tau^{2}italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is ℐ⁢𝒢⁢(aξ+(L+1)/2,bξ+𝝃⊤⁢K−1⁢𝝃/2)ℐ𝒢subscript𝑎𝜉𝐿12subscript𝑏𝜉superscript𝝃topsuperscript𝐾1𝝃2\mathcal{IG}\big{(}a_{\xi}+(L+1)/2,\ b_{\xi}+{\bm{\xi}}^{\top}K^{-1}{\bm{\xi}}% /2\big{)}caligraphic_I caligraphic_G ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( italic_L + 1 ) / 2 , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_ξ / 2 ).

C.3 Random effects

With slight abuse of notation, let ui⁢j=log ⁢Ti⁢j−g⁢(𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢𝜷)−μi⁢jsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑗log subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top𝜷subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗u_{ij}=\text{log }T_{ij}-g(\bm{x}_{ij}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$})-\mu_{ij}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each i𝑖iitalic_i, j𝑗jitalic_j. For each i𝑖iitalic_i, let

𝒖i(1)superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖1\displaystyle\bm{u}_{i}^{(1)}bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =(ui⁢1,ui⁢2,…,ui⁢m/2)⊤absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖1subscript𝑢𝑖2…subscript𝑢𝑖𝑚2top\displaystyle=(u_{i1},u_{i2},\ldots,u_{im/2})^{\top}= ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ωϵ,i(1)superscriptsubscriptΩitalic-ϵ𝑖1\displaystyle\Omega_{\epsilon,i}^{(1)}roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =diag⁢(1/σi⁢12,1/σi⁢22,…,1/σi⁢m/22)absentdiag1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖11subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖2…1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖𝑚2\displaystyle=\text{diag}(1/\sigma^{2}_{i1},1/\sigma^{2}_{i2},\ldots,1/\sigma^% {2}_{im/2})= diag ( 1 / italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 / italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , 1 / italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
𝒖i(2)superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖2\displaystyle\bm{u}_{i}^{(2)}bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =(ui⁢m,ui⁢(m−1),…,ui⁢(m/2+1))⊤absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑚subscript𝑢𝑖𝑚1…subscript𝑢𝑖𝑚21top\displaystyle=(u_{im},u_{i(m-1)},\ldots,u_{i(m/2+1)})^{\top}= ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ( italic_m - 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ( italic_m / 2 + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ωϵ,i(2)superscriptsubscriptΩitalic-ϵ𝑖2\displaystyle\Omega_{\epsilon,i}^{(2)}roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =diag⁢(1/σi⁢m2,1/σi⁢(m−1)2,…,1/σi⁢(m/2+1)2)absentdiag1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖𝑚1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖𝑚1…1subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖𝑚21\displaystyle=\text{diag}(1/\sigma^{2}_{im},1/\sigma^{2}_{i(m-1)},\ldots,1/% \sigma^{2}_{i(m/2+1)})= diag ( 1 / italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 / italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ( italic_m - 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , 1 / italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ( italic_m / 2 + 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

The conditional posterior of the random effects vector 𝒃i=(bi⁢1,…,bi⁢m/2)⊤subscript𝒃𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖1…subscript𝑏𝑖𝑚2top\bm{b}_{i}=(b_{i1},\ldots,b_{im/2})^{\top}bold_italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_m / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for each i𝑖iitalic_i, is Gaussian with mean vector 𝑸b−1⁢𝒂bsuperscriptsubscript𝑸𝑏1subscript𝒂𝑏\bm{Q}_{b}^{-1}\bm{a}_{b}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and covariance matrix 𝑸b−1superscriptsubscript𝑸𝑏1\bm{Q}_{b}^{-1}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where

𝑸bsubscript𝑸𝑏\displaystyle\bm{Q}_{b}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =Σb−1+Ωϵ,i(1)+Ωϵ,i(2),absentsuperscriptsubscriptΣ𝑏1superscriptsubscriptΩitalic-ϵ𝑖1superscriptsubscriptΩitalic-ϵ𝑖2\displaystyle=\Sigma_{b}^{-1}+\Omega_{\epsilon,i}^{(1)}+\Omega_{\epsilon,i}^{(% 2)},= roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 𝒂bsubscript𝒂𝑏\displaystyle\bm{a}_{b}bold_italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =Ωϵ,i(1)⁢𝒖i(1)+Ωϵ,i(2)⁢𝒖i(2).absentsuperscriptsubscriptΩitalic-ϵ𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖1superscriptsubscriptΩitalic-ϵ𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖2\displaystyle=\Omega_{\epsilon,i}^{(1)}\bm{u}_{i}^{(1)}+\Omega_{\epsilon,i}^{(% 2)}\bm{u}_{i}^{(2)}.= roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

C.4 Covariance matrix of random effects

The conditional posterior of ΣbsubscriptΣ𝑏\Sigma_{b}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an inverse-Wishart distribution, ℐ⁢𝒲⁢(c+n,S+∑i=1n𝒃i⁢𝒃i⊤)ℐ𝒲𝑐𝑛𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝒃𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒃𝑖top\mathcal{IW}\left(c+n,S+\sum_{i=1}^{n}\bm{b}_{i}\bm{b}_{i}^{\top}\right)caligraphic_I caligraphic_W ( italic_c + italic_n , italic_S + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where c=m/2+2𝑐𝑚22c=m/2+2italic_c = italic_m / 2 + 2 and S=(EW−ρ⁢W)−1𝑆superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑊𝜌𝑊1S=(E_{W}-\rho W)^{-1}italic_S = ( italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_ρ italic_W ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as defined in Section 2.3.3 of the main document.

C.5 Density of errors

The stick-breaking construction (Sethuraman,, 1994) allows us to express G𝐺Gitalic_G in (C.1) as

G⁢(μ,σ2)𝐺𝜇superscript𝜎2\displaystyle G(\mu,\sigma^{2})italic_G ( italic_μ , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) =∑h=1∞πh⁢δ(ϕh,sh2)⁢(μ,σ2),absentsuperscriptsubscriptℎ1subscript𝜋ℎsubscript𝛿subscriptitalic-ϕℎsubscriptsuperscript𝑠2ℎ𝜇superscript𝜎2\displaystyle=\sum_{h=1}^{\infty}\pi_{h}\delta_{(\phi_{h},\,s^{2}_{h})}(\mu,% \sigma^{2}),= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_μ , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (πh)h=1∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜋ℎℎ1\displaystyle\left(\pi_{h}\right)_{h=1}^{\infty}( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼GEM⁢(γ),similar-toabsentGEM𝛾\displaystyle\sim\text{GEM}(\gamma),∼ GEM ( italic_γ ) , (ϕh,sh2)h=1∞superscriptsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕℎsubscriptsuperscript𝑠2ℎℎ1\displaystyle\left(\phi_{h},s^{2}_{h}\right)_{h=1}^{\infty}( italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼G0,similar-toabsentsubscript𝐺0\displaystyle\sim G_{0},∼ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

where GEM stands for Griffiths, Engen and McCloskey (Pitman,, 2002), and δ(ϕ,s2)⁢(⋅)subscript𝛿italic-ϕsuperscript𝑠2⋅\delta_{(\phi,\,s^{2})}(\cdot)italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ϕ , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) is the Dirac measure at (ϕ,s2)italic-ϕsuperscript𝑠2(\phi,s^{2})( italic_ϕ , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Here, (ϕh,sh2)h=1∞superscriptsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ2ℎ1(\phi_{h},s_{h}^{2})_{h=1}^{\infty}( italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the distinct values of the atoms (μi⁢j,σi⁢j)subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗subscript𝜎𝑖𝑗(\mu_{ij},\sigma_{ij})( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) used in (C.1). Posterior sampling for the parameters of the DP mixture prior on the baseline density f𝑓fitalic_f is performed using a blocked Gibbs algorithm by Ishwaran and James, (2001) that uses a finite truncation for the number of mixture components upto a large number H.

Recall that ϵi⁢j=log ⁢Ti⁢j−bi⁢j−g⁢(𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢𝜷)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗log subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top𝜷\epsilon_{ij}=\text{log }T_{ij}-b_{ij}-g(\bm{x}_{ij}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$% \beta$})italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ), for each i𝑖iitalic_i, j𝑗jitalic_j. The hierarchical representation of a DP mixture prior of Gaussians on ϵi⁢jsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗\epsilon_{ij}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with a normal-inverse gamma base distribution G0subscript𝐺0G_{0}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a gamma prior on the concentration parameter γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ is as follows:

ϵi⁢j∣zi⁢j,ϕ,𝒔conditionalsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗subscript𝑧𝑖𝑗bold-italic-ϕ𝒔\displaystyle\epsilon_{ij}\mid z_{ij},\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$},\bm{s}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_ϕ , bold_italic_s ∼𝒩⁢(ϕzi⁢j,szi⁢j2),for each ⁢i,j.similar-toabsent𝒩subscriptitalic-ϕsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑠subscript𝑧𝑖𝑗2for each 𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(\phi_{z_{ij}},s_{z_{ij}}^{2}),\quad\text{for each% }i,j.∼ caligraphic_N ( italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , for each italic_i , italic_j .
zi⁢j∣𝝅conditionalsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑗𝝅\displaystyle z_{ij}\mid\mbox{\boldmath$\pi$}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ bold_italic_π ∼Cat⁢(π1,π2,…,πH)similar-toabsentCatsubscript𝜋1subscript𝜋2…subscript𝜋𝐻\displaystyle\sim\text{Cat}(\pi_{1},\pi_{2},\ldots,\pi_{H})∼ Cat ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
𝝅∣γconditional𝝅𝛾\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\pi$}\mid\gammabold_italic_π ∣ italic_γ ∼GEM⁢(γ)similar-toabsentGEM𝛾\displaystyle\sim\text{GEM}(\gamma)∼ GEM ( italic_γ )
ϕh,sh2subscriptitalic-ϕℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ2\displaystyle\phi_{h},s_{h}^{2}italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼𝒩⁢ℐ⁢𝒢⁢(μϵ,νϵ,aϵ,λϵ),h=1,2,…,H.formulae-sequencesimilar-toabsent𝒩ℐ𝒢subscript𝜇italic-ϵsubscript𝜈italic-ϵsubscript𝑎italic-ϵsubscript𝜆italic-ϵℎ12…𝐻\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{NIG}(\mu_{\epsilon},\nu_{\epsilon},a_{\epsilon},% \lambda_{\epsilon}),\quad h=1,2,\ldots,H.∼ caligraphic_N caligraphic_I caligraphic_G ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_h = 1 , 2 , … , italic_H .
