where ϕ=(ϕ1,ϕ2,…,ϕH)bold-italic-ϕsubscriptitalic-ϕ1subscriptitalic-ϕ2…subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐻\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$}=(\phi_{1},\phi_{2},\ldots,\phi_{H})bold_italic_ϕ = ( italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), 𝒔=(s12,s22,…,sH2)𝒔subscriptsuperscript𝑠21subscriptsuperscript𝑠22…subscriptsuperscript𝑠2𝐻\bm{s}=(s^{2}_{1},s^{2}_{2},\ldots,s^{2}_{H})bold_italic_s = ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and 𝝅=(π1,π2,…,πH)𝝅subscript𝜋1subscript𝜋2…subscript𝜋𝐻\mbox{\boldmath$\pi$}=(\pi_{1},\pi_{2},\ldots,\pi_{H})bold_italic_π = ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Note that the prior on 𝝅𝝅\pibold_italic_π can be explicitly written as π1=π1′subscript𝜋1superscriptsubscript𝜋1′\pi_{1}=\pi_{1}^{\prime}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, πh=πh′⁢∏l<h(1−πl′)subscript𝜋ℎsubscriptsuperscript𝜋′ℎsubscriptproduct𝑙ℎ1subscriptsuperscript𝜋′𝑙\pi_{h}=\pi^{\prime}_{h}\prod_{l<h}(1-\pi^{\prime}_{l})italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l < italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for 1<h<H1ℎ𝐻1<h<H1 < italic_h < italic_H, and πH=∏h=1H−1(1−πh)subscript𝜋𝐻superscriptsubscriptproductℎ1𝐻11subscript𝜋ℎ\pi_{H}=\prod_{h=1}^{H-1}(1-\pi_{h})italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where πl′∣γ∼Beta⁢(1,γ)similar-toconditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝜋𝑙′𝛾Beta1𝛾\pi_{l}^{\prime}\mid\gamma\sim\text{Beta}(1,\gamma)italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_γ ∼ Beta ( 1 , italic_γ ), l=1,…,H−1𝑙1…𝐻1l=1,\ldots,H-1italic_l = 1 , … , italic_H - 1. The atoms (μi⁢j,σi⁢j2)subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑗2(\mu_{ij},\sigma_{ij}^{2})( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) can be obtained using the distinct atoms (ϕh,sh2)h=1Hsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ2ℎ1𝐻(\phi_{h},s_{h}^{2})_{h=1}^{H}( italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the cluster labels zi⁢jsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑗z_{ij}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as follows,

μi⁢j=ϕzi⁢j,a⁢n⁢dσi⁢j2=szi⁢j2,for each ⁢i,j.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜇𝑖𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑗𝑎𝑛𝑑superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑗2superscriptsubscript𝑠subscript𝑧𝑖𝑗2for each 𝑖𝑗\mu_{ij}=\phi_{z_{ij}},\quad{and}\quad\sigma_{ij}^{2}=s_{z_{ij}}^{2},\quad% \text{for each }i,j.italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a italic_n italic_d italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , for each italic_i , italic_j .

Blocked posterior updates of the parameters are as follows:

  1. 1.

    Update 𝒛𝒛\bm{z}bold_italic_z. For each i𝑖iitalic_i, j𝑗jitalic_j,

    zi⁢j∣…∼Cat⁢(π1∗,…,πH∗),similar-toconditionalsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑗…Catsubscriptsuperscript𝜋1…subscriptsuperscript𝜋𝐻z_{ij}\mid\ldots\sim\text{Cat}\,(\pi^{*}_{1},\ldots,\pi^{*}_{H}),italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ … ∼ Cat ( italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

    where πh∗=πh⁢𝒩⁢(xi⁢j;ϕh,sh2)/∑l=1Hπl⁢𝒩⁢(xi⁢j;ϕl,sl2)subscriptsuperscript𝜋ℎsubscript𝜋ℎ𝒩subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ2superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝐻subscript𝜋𝑙𝒩subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑙2\pi^{*}_{h}=\pi_{h}\,\mathcal{N}(x_{ij}\,;\phi_{h},s_{h}^{2})\big{/}\sum_{l=1}% ^{H}\pi_{l}\,\mathcal{N}(x_{ij}\,;\phi_{l},s_{l}^{2})italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) / ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for each hℎhitalic_h.

  2. 2.

    Update 𝝅𝝅\pibold_italic_π. For h=1,2,…,H−1ℎ12…𝐻1h=1,2,\ldots,H-1italic_h = 1 , 2 , … , italic_H - 1,

    πh′∣…∼Beta⁢(nh+1,γ+∑l>hnl),similar-toconditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝜋′ℎ…Betasubscript𝑛ℎ1𝛾subscript𝑙ℎsubscript𝑛𝑙\pi^{\prime}_{h}\mid\ldots\sim\text{Beta}\,\big{(}n_{h}+1,\gamma+\sum_{l>h}n_{% l}\big{)},italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ … ∼ Beta ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , italic_γ + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l > italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

    where nh=∑i,j𝟙{zi⁢j=h}subscript𝑛ℎsubscript𝑖𝑗subscript1subscript𝑧𝑖𝑗ℎn_{h}=\sum_{i,j}\mathds{1}_{\{z_{ij}=h\}}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_h } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each hℎhitalic_h. Set π1=π1′subscript𝜋1subscriptsuperscript𝜋′1\pi_{1}=\pi^{\prime}_{1}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, πh=πh′⁢∏l<h(1−πl′)subscript𝜋ℎsubscriptsuperscript𝜋′ℎsubscriptproduct𝑙ℎ1subscriptsuperscript𝜋′𝑙\pi_{h}=\pi^{\prime}_{h}\prod_{l<h}(1-\pi^{\prime}_{l})italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l < italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for 1<h<H1ℎ𝐻1<h<H1 < italic_h < italic_H, and πH=∏l=1H−1(1−πl′)subscript𝜋𝐻superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑙1𝐻11subscriptsuperscript𝜋′𝑙\pi_{H}=\prod_{l=1}^{H-1}(1-\pi^{\prime}_{l})italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

  3. 3.

    Update ϕ,𝒔bold-italic-ϕ𝒔\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$},\bm{s}bold_italic_ϕ , bold_italic_s. For h=1,2,…,Hℎ12…𝐻h=1,2,\ldots,Hitalic_h = 1 , 2 , … , italic_H,

    sh2∣…conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ2…\displaystyle s_{h}^{2}\mid\ldotsitalic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ … ∼ℐ⁢𝒢⁢(a~ϵ,λ~ϵ)similar-toabsentℐ𝒢subscript~𝑎italic-ϵsubscript~𝜆italic-ϵ\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{IG}(\,\tilde{a}_{\epsilon},\tilde{\lambda}_{\epsilon% }\,)∼ caligraphic_I caligraphic_G ( over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over~ start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
    ϕh∣sh2,…conditionalsubscriptitalic-ϕℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ2…\displaystyle\phi_{h}\mid s_{h}^{2},\ldotsitalic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … ∼𝒩⁢(μ~ϵ,sh2/ν~ϵ)similar-toabsent𝒩subscript~𝜇italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ2subscript~𝜈italic-ϵ\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(\,\tilde{\mu}_{\epsilon},\ s_{h}^{2}/\tilde{\nu}_% {\epsilon}\,)∼ caligraphic_N ( over~ start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_ν end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

    where

    a~ϵsubscript~𝑎italic-ϵ\displaystyle\tilde{a}_{\epsilon}over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =aϵ+nh/2,absentsubscript𝑎italic-ϵsubscript𝑛ℎ2\displaystyle=a_{\epsilon}+n_{h}/2,= italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / 2 , λ~ϵsubscript~𝜆italic-ϵ\displaystyle\tilde{\lambda}_{\epsilon}over~ start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =λϵ+12⁢[∑i,j:zi⁢j=h(ϵi⁢j−ϵ¯h)2+νϵ⁢nhνϵ+nh⁢(ϵ¯h−μϵ)2],absentsubscript𝜆italic-ϵ12delimited-[]subscript:𝑖𝑗subscript𝑧𝑖𝑗ℎsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗subscript¯italic-ϵℎ2subscript𝜈italic-ϵsubscript𝑛ℎsubscript𝜈italic-ϵsubscript𝑛ℎsuperscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵℎsubscript𝜇italic-ϵ2\displaystyle=\lambda_{\epsilon}\ +\ \frac{1}{2}\,\bigg{[}\sum_{i,j:z_{ij}=h}(% \epsilon_{ij}-\bar{\epsilon}_{h})^{2}\ +\ \frac{\nu_{\epsilon}n_{h}}{\nu_{% \epsilon}+n_{h}}(\bar{\epsilon}_{h}-\mu_{\epsilon})^{2}\bigg{]},= italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j : italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( over¯ start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ,
    ν~ϵsubscript~𝜈italic-ϵ\displaystyle\tilde{\nu}_{\epsilon}over~ start_ARG italic_ν end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =νϵ+nh,absentsubscript𝜈italic-ϵsubscript𝑛ℎ\displaystyle=\nu_{\epsilon}+n_{h},= italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , μ~ϵsubscript~𝜇italic-ϵ\displaystyle\tilde{\mu}_{\epsilon}over~ start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =νϵ⁢μϵ+nh⁢ϵ¯hνϵ+nh,ϵ¯h=1nh⁢∑i,j:zi⁢j=hϵi⁢j.formulae-sequenceabsentsubscript𝜈italic-ϵsubscript𝜇italic-ϵsubscript𝑛ℎsubscript¯italic-ϵℎsubscript𝜈italic-ϵsubscript𝑛ℎsubscript¯italic-ϵℎ1subscript𝑛ℎsubscript:𝑖𝑗subscript𝑧𝑖𝑗ℎsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑗\displaystyle=\frac{\nu_{\epsilon}\mu_{\epsilon}+n_{h}\bar{\epsilon}_{h}}{\nu_% {\epsilon}+n_{h}},\quad\quad\bar{\epsilon}_{h}=\frac{1}{n_{h}}\sum_{i,j:z_{ij}% =h}\epsilon_{ij}.= divide start_ARG italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¯ start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , over¯ start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j : italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .
  4. 4.

    Update γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ.

    γ∣…∼𝒢⁢(aγ+H−1,bγ−∑h<Hlog ⁢(1−πh′)).similar-toconditional𝛾…𝒢subscript𝑎𝛾𝐻1subscript𝑏𝛾subscriptℎ𝐻log 1subscriptsuperscript𝜋′ℎ\gamma\mid\ldots\sim\mathcal{G}\bigg{(}a_{\gamma}+H-1,\,b_{\gamma}-\sum_{h<H}% \text{log }(1-\pi^{\prime}_{h})\bigg{)}.italic_γ ∣ … ∼ caligraphic_G ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_H - 1 , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h < italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT log ( 1 - italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) .

C.6 Time to a missing tooth

Let si⁢j=Si⁢j⁢(ci⁢j)subscript𝑠𝑖𝑗subscript𝑆𝑖𝑗subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗s_{ij}=S_{ij}(c_{ij})italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) denote the state of tooth j𝑗jitalic_j of subject i𝑖iitalic_i at its observed inspection time Ci⁢j=ci⁢jsubscript𝐶𝑖𝑗subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗C_{ij}=c_{ij}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The conditional posterior distribution of log ⁢Ti⁢jlog subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗\text{log }T_{ij}log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each i𝑖iitalic_i, j𝑗jitalic_j, is a truncated Gaussian with mean g⁢(𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢𝜷)+bi⁢j+μi⁢j𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top𝜷subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗g(\bm{x}_{ij}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$})+b_{ij}+\mu_{ij}italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and variance σi⁢j2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖𝑗2\sigma_{ij}^{2}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where the truncation region is given by

𝒞log ⁢Ti⁢j={log ⁢Ti⁢j∈ℝ:ci⁢j∑l=1si⁢j+1Ri⁢j(l)<Ti⁢j≤ci⁢j∑l=1si⁢jRi⁢j(l)}.subscript𝒞log subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗conditional-setlog subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗ℝsubscript𝑐𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑙1subscript𝑠𝑖𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝑙subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑙1subscript𝑠𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝑙\mathcal{C}_{\text{log }T_{ij}}=\left\{\text{log }T_{ij}\in{\mathbb{R}}:\ % \frac{c_{ij}}{\sum_{l=1}^{s_{ij}+1}R_{ij}^{\,(l)}}\ <\ T_{ij}\ \leq\ \frac{c_{% ij}}{\sum_{l=1}^{s_{ij}}R_{ij}^{\,(l)}}\right\}.caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R : divide start_ARG italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG < italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG } .

C.7 Relative disease increment times

The conditional posterior distribution of the relative time increment to each disease state 𝑹i⁢j=(Ri⁢j(1),Ri⁢j(2),…,Ri⁢j(K))subscript𝑹𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗2…superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝐾\bm{R}_{ij}=\left(R_{ij}^{\,(1)},R_{ij}^{\,(2)},\ldots,R_{ij}^{\,(K)}\right)bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_K ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for each i𝑖iitalic_i, j𝑗jitalic_j, is a truncated Dirichlet distribution with parameters (α1,…,αK)subscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝐾\left(\alpha_{1},\ldots,\alpha_{K}\right)( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and the region of truncation given by

𝒞𝑹i⁢j={𝑹i⁢j∈𝕊K−1:ci⁢j∑l=1si⁢j+1Ri⁢j(l)<Ti⁢j≤ci⁢j∑l=1si⁢jRi⁢j(l)},subscript𝒞subscript𝑹𝑖𝑗conditional-setsubscript𝑹𝑖𝑗subscript𝕊𝐾1subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑙1subscript𝑠𝑖𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝑙subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑙1subscript𝑠𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝑙\mathcal{C}_{\bm{R}_{ij}}=\left\{\bm{R}_{ij}\in\mathbb{S}_{K-1}:\ \frac{c_{ij}% }{\sum_{l=1}^{s_{ij}+1}R_{ij}^{\,(l)}}\ <\ T_{ij}\ \leq\ \frac{c_{ij}}{\sum_{l% =1}^{s_{ij}}R_{ij}^{\,(l)}}\right\},caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : divide start_ARG italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG < italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG } ,

where 𝕊K−1subscript𝕊𝐾1\mathbb{S}_{K-1}blackboard_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes a simplex of dimension K𝐾Kitalic_K, and si⁢jsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑗s_{ij}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is as defined in Section C.6. We define Vi⁢j(k)=∑l=1kRi⁢j(l)superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖𝑗𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝑙V_{ij}^{(k)}=\sum_{l=1}^{k}R_{ij}^{(l)}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, k=1,2,…,K−1𝑘12…𝐾1k=1,2,\ldots,K-1italic_k = 1 , 2 , … , italic_K - 1, and obtain samples from the posterior distribution using properties of the Dirichlet distribution and depending on si⁢jsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑗s_{ij}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as follows:

  1. 1.

    si⁢j=0subscript𝑠𝑖𝑗0s_{ij}=0italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.

    1. a.

      Sample Ri⁢j(1)∼similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗1absentR_{ij}^{(1)}\simitalic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ Beta(α1,α2+⋯+αK)subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2⋯subscript𝛼𝐾(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2}+\cdots+\alpha_{K})( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ⋯ + italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) truncated on (ci⁢j/Ti⁢j,1)subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗1(c_{ij}/T_{ij},1)( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 ).

    2. b.

      Sample (Ri⁢j(2),…,Ri⁢j(K))∼(1−Ri⁢j(1))⁢ Dir⁢(α2,…,αK)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗2…superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗1 Dirsubscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝐾(R_{ij}^{(2)},\ldots,R_{ij}^{(K)})\sim(1-R_{ij}^{(1)})\text{ Dir}(\alpha_{2},% \ldots,\alpha_{K})( italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_K ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∼ ( 1 - italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) Dir ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

  2. 2.

    si⁢j=ksubscript𝑠𝑖𝑗𝑘s_{ij}=kitalic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k, k=1,2,…,K−2𝑘12…𝐾2k=1,2,\ldots,K-2italic_k = 1 , 2 , … , italic_K - 2.

    1. a.

      Sample Vi⁢j(k)∼similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖𝑗𝑘absentV_{ij}^{(k)}\simitalic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ Beta(∑l=1kαl,∑l=k+1Kαl)superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑘subscript𝛼𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑙\big{(}\sum_{l=1}^{k}\alpha_{l},\,\sum_{l=k+1}^{K}\alpha_{l}\big{)}( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) truncated on (0,ci⁢j/Ti⁢j)0subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗(0,c_{ij}/T_{ij})( 0 , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

    3. c.

      Set Ri⁢j(k+1)=Ui⁢j⁢(1−Vi⁢j(k))superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝑘1subscript𝑈𝑖𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖𝑗𝑘R_{ij}^{(k+1)}=U_{ij}(1-V_{ij}^{(k)})italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

C.8 Dirichlet parameters of the relative disease increment times

The conditional posterior of parameters 𝜶=(α1,…,αK)𝜶subscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝐾\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$}=(\alpha_{1},\ldots,\alpha_{K})bold_italic_α = ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of the Dirichlet distribution on 𝑹i⁢jsubscript𝑹𝑖𝑗\bm{R}_{ij}bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given by

p⁢(𝜶∣…)∝∏k=1K𝒢⁢(αk;aα,bα)⁢∏i,jDir⁢(𝑹i⁢j;𝜶)proportional-to𝑝conditional𝜶…superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝐾𝒢subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝑎𝛼subscript𝑏𝛼subscriptproduct𝑖𝑗Dirsubscript𝑹𝑖𝑗𝜶p(\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$}\mid\ldots)\propto\prod_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{G}(\alpha_% {k}\,;a_{\alpha},b_{\alpha})\ \prod_{i,j}\text{Dir}(\bm{R}_{ij}\,;\mbox{% \boldmath$\alpha$})italic_p ( bold_italic_α ∣ … ) ∝ ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_G ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Dir ( bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_α )

Samples from this non-standard posterior are obtained by using a random walk Metropolis within Gibbs with a Gaussian proposal whose variance is tuned to have a acceptance ratio between 0.2−0.40.20.40.2-0.40.2 - 0.4.

Appendix D Estimation of state occupation and transition probabilities

The marginal distribution of the time to a missing tooth Ti⁢jsubscript𝑇𝑖𝑗T_{ij}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for each i𝑖iitalic_i, j𝑗jitalic_j as described in Section 2.4 of the main document, is given by

log ⁢Ti⁢j∼∑h=1∞πh⁢𝒩⁢(g⁢(𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢𝜷)+ϕh,σb,j2+sh2),similar-tolog subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptℎ1subscript𝜋ℎ𝒩𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top𝜷subscriptitalic-ϕℎsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑏𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑠2ℎ\text{log }T_{ij}\sim\sum_{h=1}^{\infty}\pi_{h}\,\mathcal{N}\left(\,g(\bm{x}_{% ij}^{\top}\,\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$})+\phi_{h},\ \sigma^{2}_{b,j}+s^{2}_{h}\,% \right),log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N ( italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β ) + italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (D.1)

where σb,j2=𝒛j⊤⁢Σb⁢𝒛jsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑏𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒛𝑗topsubscriptΣ𝑏subscript𝒛𝑗\sigma^{2}_{b,j}=\bm{z}_{j}^{\top}\Sigma_{b}\,\bm{z}_{j}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝒛j⊤superscriptsubscript𝒛𝑗top\bm{z}_{j}^{\top}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes the j𝑗jitalic_jth row of 𝒁𝒁\bm{Z}bold_italic_Z. The number of mixture components in (D.1) is truncated upto a large number H𝐻Hitalic_H, as described in Section C.5.

Let {𝜷(d),𝝃(d),Σb(d),𝝅(d),ϕ(d),𝒔(d),𝜶(d):d=1,2,…⁢M}conditional-setsuperscript𝜷𝑑superscript𝝃𝑑superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑏𝑑superscript𝝅𝑑superscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑑superscript𝒔𝑑superscript𝜶𝑑𝑑12…𝑀\{\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}^{(d)},\mbox{\boldmath$\xi$}^{(d)},\Sigma_{b}^{(d)},% \mbox{\boldmath$\pi$}^{(d)},\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$}^{(d)},\bm{s}^{(d)},\mbox{% \boldmath$\alpha$}^{(d)}:d=1,2,\ldots M\}{ bold_italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_ϕ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_d = 1 , 2 , … italic_M } denote the set of M𝑀Mitalic_M posterior samples of the model parameters. In the following, we outline the steps for the estimation of the state occupation probability (SOP) and transition probability (TP) for tooth j𝑗jitalic_j of a subject with any given choice of covariates, corresponding to each posterior sample d𝑑ditalic_d, d=1,2,…,M𝑑12…𝑀d=1,2,\ldots,Mitalic_d = 1 , 2 , … , italic_M. Henceforth, the subscripts i⁢j𝑖𝑗ijitalic_i italic_j are dropped for clarity of notation.

Step 1. Construct g(d)⁢(𝒙⊤⁢𝜷(d))=∑l=0Lξl(d)⁢ψl⁢(𝒙⊤⁢𝜷(d))superscript𝑔𝑑superscript𝒙topsuperscript𝜷𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑙𝑑subscript𝜓𝑙superscript𝒙topsuperscript𝜷𝑑g^{(d)}\left(\bm{x}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}^{(d)}\right)=\sum_{l=0}^{L}% \,\xi_{l}^{(d)}\ \psi_{l}\left(\bm{x}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}^{(d)}\right)italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Step 2. Draw B𝐵Bitalic_B independent samples from joint distribution of 𝑹𝑹\bm{R}bold_italic_R, i.e.

𝑹1,…,𝑹B∼Dir ⁢(𝜶(d))similar-tosubscript𝑹1…subscript𝑹𝐵Dir superscript𝜶𝑑\bm{R}_{1},\ldots,\bm{R}_{B}\sim\text{Dir }(\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$}^{(d)})bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ Dir ( bold_italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

Step 3. Draw B𝐵Bitalic_B independent samples from the marginal distribution of T𝑇Titalic_T hierarchically as follows : For i′=1,2,…,Bsuperscript𝑖′12…𝐵i^{\prime}=1,2,\ldots,Bitalic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 , 2 , … , italic_B,

  1. (i)

    Draw Vi′∼Cat⁢(π1(d),…,πH(d))similar-tosubscript𝑉superscript𝑖′Catsuperscriptsubscript𝜋1𝑑…superscriptsubscript𝜋𝐻𝑑V_{i^{\prime}}\sim\text{Cat}\left(\pi_{1}^{(d)},\ldots,\pi_{H}^{(d)}\right)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ Cat ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

  2. (ii)

    Given Vi′=hsubscript𝑉superscript𝑖′ℎV_{i^{\prime}}=hitalic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_h, draw Yi′∼𝒩⁢(g(d)⁢(𝒙⊤⁢𝜷(d))+ϕh(d),(σb2)(d)+(sh2)(d))similar-tosubscript𝑌superscript𝑖′𝒩superscript𝑔𝑑superscript𝒙topsuperscript𝜷𝑑superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕℎ𝑑superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑏2𝑑superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑠2ℎ𝑑Y_{i^{\prime}}\sim\mathcal{N}\left(\,g^{(d)}(\bm{x}^{\top}\mbox{\boldmath$% \beta$}^{(d)})+\phi_{h}^{(d)},\ (\sigma_{b}^{2})^{(d)}+(s^{2}_{h})^{(d)}\,\right)italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

  3. (iii)

    Set Ti′=exp⁡{Yi′}subscript𝑇superscript𝑖′subscript𝑌superscript𝑖′T_{i^{\prime}}=\exp{\{Y_{i^{\prime}}\}}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_exp { italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }.

Step 4. The SOPs for a given t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0italic_t ≥ 0, can be expressed in terms of T𝑇Titalic_T and 𝑹𝑹\bm{R}bold_italic_R by substituting equation (2.3) in equation (2.1) from Section 2.1 of the main document. We define the corresponding indicator functions ηksubscript𝜂𝑘\eta_{k}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each state k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}italic_k ∈ caligraphic_K,

ηk⁢(t;T,𝑹)={𝟙⁢(t<T⁢R(1)),k=0𝟙⁢(T⁢∑l=1kR(l)≤t<T⁢∑l=1k+1R(l)),k=1,…,K−1𝟙⁢(T≤t),k=Ksubscript𝜂𝑘𝑡𝑇𝑹cases1𝑡𝑇superscript𝑅1𝑘01𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑘superscript𝑅𝑙𝑡𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑘1superscript𝑅𝑙𝑘1…𝐾11𝑇𝑡𝑘𝐾\eta_{k}(t\,;\,T,\bm{R})=\begin{cases}\mathds{1}\left(t\ <T\,R^{(1)}\right),&k% =0\\ \mathds{1}\left(T\,\sum_{l=1}^{k}{R^{(l)}}\leq\ t\ <T\,\sum_{l=1}^{k+1}R^{(l)}% \right),&k=1,\ldots,K-1\\ \mathds{1}\left(T\leq t\right),&k=K\end{cases}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ; italic_T , bold_italic_R ) = { start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_1 ( italic_t < italic_T italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , end_CELL start_CELL italic_k = 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_1 ( italic_T ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_t < italic_T ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , end_CELL start_CELL italic_k = 1 , … , italic_K - 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_1 ( italic_T ≤ italic_t ) , end_CELL start_CELL italic_k = italic_K end_CELL end_ROW

and estimate the probabilities with their Monte Carlo averages,

p^k(d)⁢(t)=1B⁢∑i′=1Bηk⁢(t;Ti′,𝑹i′),k∈𝒦.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript^𝑝𝑑𝑘𝑡1𝐵superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑖′1𝐵subscript𝜂𝑘𝑡subscript𝑇superscript𝑖′subscript𝑹superscript𝑖′𝑘𝒦\widehat{p}^{\,(d)}_{k}(t)=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{i^{\prime}=1}^{B}\eta_{k}(t\,;\,T_% {i^{\prime}},\bm{R}_{i^{\prime}}),\quad k\in\mathcal{K}.over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_B end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ; italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_k ∈ caligraphic_K .

Step 5. The TPs defined as a conditional probability can similarly be estimated by the Monte Carlo method as follows,

p^r⁢s(d)⁢(u,t)=∑i′=1Bηs⁢(t+u;Ti′,𝑹i′)⁢ηr⁢(u;Ti′,𝑹i′)∑i′=1Bηr⁢(u;Ti′,𝑹i′),r≤s;r,s∈𝒦.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript^𝑝𝑑𝑟𝑠𝑢𝑡superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑖′1𝐵subscript𝜂𝑠𝑡𝑢subscript𝑇superscript𝑖′subscript𝑹superscript𝑖′subscript𝜂𝑟𝑢subscript𝑇superscript𝑖′subscript𝑹superscript𝑖′superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑖′1𝐵subscript𝜂𝑟𝑢subscript𝑇superscript𝑖′subscript𝑹superscript𝑖′formulae-sequence𝑟𝑠𝑟𝑠𝒦\widehat{p}^{\,(d)}_{rs}(u,t)=\frac{\sum_{i^{\prime}=1}^{B}\eta_{s}(t+u\,;\,T_% {i^{\prime}},\bm{R}_{i^{\prime}})\ \eta_{r}(u\,;\,T_{i^{\prime}},\bm{R}_{i^{% \prime}})}{\sum_{i^{\prime}=1}^{B}\eta_{r}(u\,;\,T_{i^{\prime}},\bm{R}_{i^{% \prime}})},\quad r\leq s\,;\ r,s\in\mathcal{K}.over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u , italic_t ) = divide start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t + italic_u ; italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ; italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ; italic_r , italic_s ∈ caligraphic_K .

Appendix E Additional details on the GAAD data analysis

E.1 Choice of hyperparameters

In this section, we elaborate on the choice of hyperparameters which characterize the prior distributions on our model parameters, used in the GAAD data analysis.

Regression parameters: We use a zero-mean Gaussian prior on ~⁢𝜷~absent𝜷\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β and set its prior variance σβ2=100superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛽2100\sigma_{\beta}^{2}=100italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 100. However, any arbitrary choice for σβ2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛽2\sigma_{\beta}^{2}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT would suffice, as long as it is positive. Since ~⁢𝜷~absent𝜷\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β is scaled by its norm, the variance of the induced prior on β𝛽\betaitalic_β remains unaffected by the specific choice of σβ2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝛽2\sigma_{\beta}^{2}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Additionally, one can specify a non-zero mean μ𝜇\muitalic_μ for ~⁢𝜷~absent𝜷\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β to reflect prior knowledge about certain covariates. To accommodate this, we need to apply a simple modification to the elliptical slice sampling algorithm for posterior sampling of ~⁢𝜷~absent𝜷\widetilde{}\mbox{\boldmath$\beta$}over~ start_ARG end_ARG bold_italic_β to adjust for its non-zero mean. Details on implementing this adjustment can be found in Section 3.3 of Murray et al., (2010).

Monotone link function: The length-scale parameter ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ of the Matérn covariance kernel (discussed in Section C.2) controls the rate of decay of the covariance with the inter-location distances, and is usually chosen to ensure very small correlation between two distant points in the covariate space. The parameter ν𝜈\nuitalic_ν controls the smoothness of the monotone function g𝑔gitalic_g. We know that the reproducing kernel Hilbert space of a Gaussian process equipped with Matérn covariance kernel with smoothness parameter ν𝜈\nuitalic_ν consists of functions belonging to the Hölder class of smoothness ν+0.5𝜈0.5\nu+0.5italic_ν + 0.5. Following Ray et al., (2020), we use default choices of ν=0.75𝜈0.75\nu=0.75italic_ν = 0.75, with ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ chosen such that the correlation at a maximum possible separation between the covariates equals 0.050.050.050.05. When using a smooth relaxation of the indicator function in the constrained prior of the basis coefficients in equation (2.9) of the main document, we set η=100𝜂100\eta=100italic_η = 100. To have a non-informative inverse-gamma ℐ⁢𝒢⁢(aξ,bξ)ℐ𝒢subscript𝑎𝜉subscript𝑏𝜉\mathcal{IG}(a_{\xi},b_{\xi})caligraphic_I caligraphic_G ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) prior on τ2superscript𝜏2\tau^{2}italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, both the parameters are set to 0.010.010.010.01.

Covariance matrix of spatial random effects: The mean of an inverse-Wishart distribution with degrees of freedom c𝑐citalic_c and m/2×m/2𝑚2𝑚2m/2\times m/2italic_m / 2 × italic_m / 2 scale matrix S𝑆Sitalic_S is S/(c−m/2−1)𝑆𝑐𝑚21S/(c-m/2-1)italic_S / ( italic_c - italic_m / 2 - 1 ). Here, c𝑐citalic_c controls how informative the prior is. We set c=m/2+2𝑐𝑚22c=m/2+2italic_c = italic_m / 2 + 2 and S=(EW−ρ⁢W)−1𝑆superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑊𝜌𝑊1S=(E_{W}-\rho\,W)^{-1}italic_S = ( italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_ρ italic_W ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, such that the prior is proper (c>m/2+1𝑐𝑚21c>m/2+1italic_c > italic_m / 2 + 1), and is loosely centered around a CAR model, where the degree of spatial dependence ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ is set at 0.90.90.90.9.

Density of errors: The distinct atoms (ϕh,sh2)subscriptitalic-ϕℎsubscriptsuperscript𝑠2ℎ(\phi_{h},s^{2}_{h})( italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) specifying the DP mixture of Gaussians are endowed with a conjugate normal-inverse gamma 𝒩⁢ℐ⁢𝒢⁢(μϵ,νϵ,aϵ,λϵ)𝒩ℐ𝒢subscript𝜇italic-ϵsubscript𝜈italic-ϵsubscript𝑎italic-ϵsubscript𝜆italic-ϵ\mathcal{NIG}(\mu_{\epsilon},\nu_{\epsilon},a_{\epsilon},\lambda_{\epsilon})caligraphic_N caligraphic_I caligraphic_G ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) prior, i.e.,

sh2∣aϵ,λϵconditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ2subscript𝑎italic-ϵsubscript𝜆italic-ϵ\displaystyle s_{h}^{2}\mid a_{\epsilon},\lambda_{\epsilon}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ℐ⁢𝒢⁢(aϵ,λϵ),similar-toabsentℐ𝒢subscript𝑎italic-ϵsubscript𝜆italic-ϵ\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{IG}(a_{\epsilon},\lambda_{\epsilon})\,,∼ caligraphic_I caligraphic_G ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , ϕh∣sh2,μϵ,νϵconditionalsubscriptitalic-ϕℎsubscriptsuperscript𝑠2ℎsubscript𝜇italic-ϵsubscript𝜈italic-ϵ\displaystyle\phi_{h}\mid s^{2}_{h},\,\mu_{\epsilon},\,\nu_{\epsilon}italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼𝒩⁢(μϵ,sh2/νϵ).similar-toabsent𝒩subscript𝜇italic-ϵsubscriptsuperscript𝑠2ℎsubscript𝜈italic-ϵ\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(\mu_{\epsilon},s^{2}_{h}/\nu_{\epsilon})\,.∼ caligraphic_N ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

We set μϵ=0subscript𝜇italic-ϵ0\mu_{\epsilon}=0italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, νϵ=1subscript𝜈italic-ϵ1\nu_{\epsilon}=1italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, and aϵsubscript𝑎italic-ϵa_{\epsilon}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, bϵsubscript𝑏italic-ϵb_{\epsilon}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are chosen to have the prior mean and variance of sh2superscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ2s_{h}^{2}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as 0.10.10.10.1 and 10101010, respectively. The parameters of the gamma 𝒢(aγ\mathcal{G}(a_{\gamma}caligraphic_G ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, λγ)\lambda_{\gamma})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_γ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) prior on the concentration parameter γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ is chosen so that its mean and variance are 1111 and 10101010, respectively. We set the truncation level of the mixture components at H=10𝐻10H=10italic_H = 10.

Dirichlet parameters of the relative disease increment times: Since the information on the state transition times from the observed data is weak, we use a weakly informative gamma 𝒢(aα\mathcal{G}(a_{\alpha}caligraphic_G ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, λα)\lambda_{\alpha})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) prior on the Dirichlet parameters αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, k=0,1,…,K𝑘01…𝐾k=0,1,\ldots,Kitalic_k = 0 , 1 , … , italic_K, that specifies the distribution of the relative disease increment times Ri⁢jsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗R_{ij}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so that the prior does not unduly influence the posterior distribution. We choose aαsubscript𝑎𝛼a_{\alpha}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and λαsubscript𝜆𝛼\lambda_{\alpha}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, such that the prior mean and variance are 1111 and 100100100100, respectively.

E.2 Selection of knots in the basis expansion of the monotone link function

We vary the number of knot points L∈{10,15,20,…,45}𝐿101520…45L\in\{10,15,20,\ldots,45\}italic_L ∈ { 10 , 15 , 20 , … , 45 } in the basis expansion of the monotone link function, given in equation (2.7) of the main document. By fitting the four competing spatial models to the GAAD data (see Section 3 of the main document for details), we calculate the corresponding values of Watanabe-Akaike information criterion (WAIC) for each knot point. In Figure E.1, the plotted WAIC values against the number of knots reveal a clear pattern: the S-GP-DP model consistently exhibits the lowest WAIC across all knot points, followed by the S-BP-DP model. Models employing DP errors consistently outperform those with normal errors in terms of WAIC. For the S-GP-DP model, the lowest WAIC occurs at L=35𝐿35L=35italic_L = 35, followed by L=30𝐿30L=30italic_L = 30 with a difference of less than 10101010. Consequently, we select L=30𝐿30L=30italic_L = 30 for our analysis of the GAAD data.

E.3 Plot of model based residuals

We define the model based residuals as ei⁢j=log ⁢Ti⁢j−bi⁢j−g⁢(𝒙i⁢j⊤⁢β)−ϕzi⁢jsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑗log subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑗top𝛽subscriptitalic-ϕsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑗e_{ij}=\text{log }T_{ij}-b_{ij}-g(\bm{x}_{ij}^{\top}\beta)-\phi_{z_{ij}}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = log italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_β ) - italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each i𝑖iitalic_i, j𝑗jitalic_j. Figure E.2 shows boxplots of these residuals for the S-GP-DP and S-GP-N models. It is evident that the model with a normal prior for the error density exhibits greater variability in residuals around zero in comparison to the model employing a DP mixture prior.

Appendix F Additional simulation results

In this section, we present the results of Simulations 1 and 2 when the underlying true link function is g20superscriptsubscript𝑔20g_{2}^{0}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Boxplots of the mean squared error (MSE), relative bias (RB) and mean integrated squared error (MISE) and barplots of the coverage probability (CP) across the 100 replicates over increasing n𝑛nitalic_n under Simulations 1 and 2 are shown in Figures F.1 and F.2, respectively.

Under Simulation 1, where the model is correctly specified, both the S-GP-DP and S-GP-N models demonstrate superior estimation performance compared to models employing the BP basis. The boxplots of MSE, RB, and MISE exhibit a decreasing trend as sample sizes increases, indicating that posterior estimates from models with constrained GP basis are consistent. The desired 95%percent9595\%95 % coverage is attained by each β^jsubscript^𝛽𝑗\hat{\beta}_{j}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for both small and large sample sizes. The S-BP-N model shows comparable performance for sample sizes (50, 100, 300) but the performance deteriorates for sample size 500. The S-BP-DP model demonstrates uniformly poor performance for all sample sizes.

Under Simulation 2, where the model is misspecified, the S-GP-DP and S-GP-N models consistently outperform the S-BP-DP and S-BP-N models. The GP models deliver satisfactory estimation performances in terms of MSE, RB and MISE. The GP models attain the desired 95%percent9595\%95 % coverage across all sample sizes. While S-BP-N maintains the nominal coverage rate, the coverage of S-BP-DP shows a decline as the sample size increases, dropping to 1%percent11\%1 % for n=500𝑛500n=500italic_n = 500. The regression parameter estimates from S-BP-N remain robust for all sample sizes, but the estimation of the link function deteriorates with an increase in sample size. Estimation of the link function and the regression parameters are seen to be poor under the S-BP-DP model. In summary, estimates from the GP models are seen to be robust under model misspecification. Estimation of the link function under the S-BP-N model tends to suffer for large sample sizes, while the S-BP-DP model delivers poor performances across all sample sizes.

Generated on Fri Jul 11 22:26:47 2025 by LaTeXML
